This case outlines a typical presentation of heart failure in a patient with multiple risk factors including advancing age  African American ethnicity  hypertension  ischemic heart disease  and diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of increased shortness of breath  fatigue and swelling in the ankles and feet. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the last two weeks  with a notable increase in breathlessness at night and a need to sleep with more pillows. He also reports unintentional weight gain of around 5 pounds over the last week.  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension for the last 10 years  managed with Lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 5 years  managed with Metformin. He quit smoking 15 years ago  but had a 20 pack-year smoking history prior to that. His family history includes his father who died of myocardial infarction at 72 and his mother who suffered from hypertension.  Mr. A denies chest pain  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or palpitations. His appetite has remained normal but his activity level has declined due to fatigue. His alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions and he has no history of illicit drug use.   On physical examination  the patient appears mildly distressed with labored breathing. Vitals on entry show BP: 150/90mmhg  HR: 90bpm  RR: 22 breaths per minute  SpO2: 92% on room air. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal crepitations  and the cardiovascular examination shows a raised JVP and peripheral pitting edema. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Given his symptoms  past medical history and physical examination findings  a working diagnosis of heart failure is made.

Patient Demographic Information:   Mrs. Alice Thompson  a 67-year-old Caucasian female who is a retired high school teacher. She is a widow living alone and has three adult children. She is a non-smoker and reports that she drinks alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. Thompson presents with a 4 weeks history of gradually worsening shortness of breath both at rest and on exertion. She reports difficulty in climbing steps and walking short distances without losing breath. She also reports that she had to sleep with multiple pillows for few weeks due to difficulty in breathing when lying flat. She has noticed sudden weight gain and swelling in her ankles and feet. She does not have chest pain  palpitations or fainting spells.  Past Medical History:  She has a history of hypertension which was diagnosed 10 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus since 8 years  and was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 5 years ago. She has also been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage 3. She had a hip replacement surgery 5 year ago.   Current Medications:  She is on Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  Apixaban for atrial fibrillation and nutritional supplements for Chronic Kidney Disease.   Family history:  Her father died from a heart attack at age 59 and her mother had a stroke at age 70.   Social History:  She is a widow and lives with her older daughter. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She drinks red wine about once or twice a week  1-2 glasses each time. She has a sedentary lifestyle and is part of a book club. Her diet is usually balanced but she admits to indulging in sweets occasionally.  Review of Systems:  She reports increasing fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance over the past month. She denies nausea  vomiting  chest pain  abdominal pain or changes in bowel habits. She has no cough or fever. She has been urinating normally and has no pain or burning.   Physical Examination Information:  Upon physical examination  the patient appears distressed due to breathlessness. Her pulse rate is irregular at 96 beats per minute  blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. She has pitting edema in both lower limbs and made worse by standing. On auscultation  lungs sound clear bilaterally but there are rales in the lower lobes. Heart sounds reveal third heart sound (S3 gallop) which is often an early diagnostic sign of heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 64-year-old African American man.  Presenting Complaint: He presents to the clinic with symptoms of increasing shortness of breath  persistent coughing especially at night  increased fatigue  unexplained rapid weight gain  and swelling in his ankles  feet  and abdomen.  History of Present Illness: On further inquiry  Mr. Jones admits that his symptoms have been progressively worsening over the last two months. He reports that he is unable to lie flat for sleep because of breathlessness and uses several pillows to prop himself up. He also mentions an increasing lack of appetite and nausea.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a known history of hypertension  diabetes type 2  and had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) five years ago. He also has a 30-year history of smoking but quit 3 years ago.  Medications: He is currently on metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and aspirin for heart disease prophylaxis.   Family History: His father died at the age of 70 from a heart condition  and his mother  72  has hypertension and diabetes.  Social History: Mr. Jones is married and retired. He doesn't exercise regularly and reports a diet high in saturated fats and sodium. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 3 years ago. He doesn't consume alcohol.   Review of Systems: Denies chest pain  palpitations  or lightheadedness. He has noted an increase in urination at night.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Jones appears breathless at rest. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  his heart rate is 82 bpm  and he is overweight. There is evident pitting edema in his lower extremities up to the shin and at his sacrum  with evidence of hepatojugular reflux. Auscultation of the chest reveals an S3 heart sound and bibasal lung crackles.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. David Jones  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with the chief complaint of shortness of breath on exertion and increasing fatigue over the past several months. He mentions these symptoms have steadily worsened  with decreased exercise tolerance and experiencing difficulty in doing regular activities like climbing stairs or walking short distances. He also reports increasing episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and has noticed a weight gain of 10 pounds over the last two weeks.   Mr. Jones is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  quitting approximately 15 years ago. He has a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are relatively well controlled on medication. He has a positive family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from a heart attack at age of 65  and his mother suffering from stroke at age of 76.  He had an acute myocardial infarction 5 years ago  for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He is currently on aspirin  metoprolol  lisinopril  and metformin. His heart rate is 85 bpm and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. He is overweight with a BMI of 30.  Upon physical exam  there is evidence of peripheral edema  jugular venous distension  and bibasilar crackles heard upon pulmonary auscultation  indicative of fluid overload. These symptoms  combined with his history suggesting evidence of progressively worsening congestive heart failure. His lab results reveal elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP).

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 65-year-old African-American female who presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  particularly on exertion. She also reports intermittent chest pain  fatigue  persistent cough producing white sputum  and notable swelling in her ankles and legs.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled on medication  and she underwent a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. Her mother and grandfather also had heart disease.  She has been taking Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes and she is adherent to these medications. She denies any use of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drugs.   Her vital signs are: BP:154/96mmHg  HR: 102 bpm  RR: 22 breaths per minute  Temp: 98.6°F  SpO2: 91% on room air.  On examination  she's alert but appears distressed due to difficulty in breathing. Cardiac exam reveals an S3 gallop. Lung auscultation shows basilar crackles. Her lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema.  Compliance to her antihypertensive medication has been good but her blood pressure reading today is slightly on the higher side. The new onset of these symptoms along with her past medical history and physical exam findings indicate the likelihood of congestive heart failure.   Further investigation with an echocardiogram  chest X-ray  and laboratory studies (BNP level  comprehensive metabolic panel  CBC) are advised to confirm the diagnosis and guide the management plan.

Patient Information: Mr. Patterson is a 68-year-old African American male.   Chief Complaint: He presents with increasing shortness of breath(orthopnea) and swelling in his lower limbs over the last two weeks.   History of Present Illness: Patient notes progressive shortness of breath especially while lying down  necessitating the use of three pillows to sleep comfortably and waking up at night gasping for air(paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). He also reports recent increase in lower extremity swelling and a weight gain of ~5kg over the same period. He denies chest pain  palpitations or syncope.   Past Medical History: Mr. Patterson has a history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  which are both moderately controlled with medication. He suffered from a myocardial infarction three years ago.   Social History: The patient is a retired metal worker  married with two adult children. He has a 20 pack-year history of tobacco smoking but quit around the time of his myocardial infarction  does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs.   Review of Systems: He reports overall fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance  having to stop halfway up the stairs due to breathlessness.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable with blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  pulse of 88 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure  bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation  a displaced apex beat  a third heart sound on cardiac auscultation  and pitting edema in the lower extremities.   Impression: Given his symptoms and physical exam findings  Mr. Patterson is likely experiencing decompensated heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  67-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  residing in a suburban neighborhood.  Chief Complaint: Progressive shortness of breath over the last few weeks  particularly when lying down or during light physical activity. Noticeable fatigue  leg swelling and unexplained weight gain.  Medical History: Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension approximately 5 years ago  poorly controlled despite treatment. History of two previous myocardial infarctions (3 and 5 years ago  respectively). No history of surgeries or severe allergies. Family history of cardiovascular disease; both parents died of heart disease  father at 59  mother at 64.  Medications: Current medications include Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and Aspirin 81mg daily for cardiovascular prevention.   Assessment: The patient's report of symptoms such as shortness of breath  fatigue  leg swelling  and weight gain  combined with his healthcare history of hypertension  diabetes and myocardial infarctions suggest advanced heart failure. More comprehensive evaluation  including lab tests  ECG  and echocardiogram necessary to confirm the diagnosis  and to stage the disease for appropriate management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a two-week history of increasing shortness of breath  severe fatigue  and significant ankle swelling. He states that his symptoms have been progressing over the last couple of weeks  noting that he is now unable to lie flat in bed due to breathlessness and has been sleeping in a semi-upright position. He specifically mentions a weight gain of about 8lbs over the last week  which is unusual for him.  His past medical history reveals a diagnosis of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Both conditions have generally been well managed with medications including Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. Medical records also indicate he suffered a myocardial infarction about 5 years ago. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  and he reports minimal alcohol use.   His family history is significant for heart disease; his father died at the age of 65 due to heart attack.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Maria Gonzalez is a 68-year-old Hispanic female who presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath  especially with exertion  and swelling in the lower limbs for the past two weeks. She reports that she has had a dry cough and difficulties with sleeping flat in her bed due to breathlessness. Day-to-day activities like walking to the corner store have become more exhausting. Her symptoms seem to worsen at night.   She has a known medical history of hypertension for which she was prescribed Lisinopril 2 years ago but has been inconsistent in taking her medications. Her symptoms are suggestive of difficulty keeping up with dietary recommendations  specifically salt and fluid restrictions. She is a non-smoker and drinks approximately 3-4 glasses of wine per week. Her family history is significant for her father passing away from a heart attack in his early seventies.  She lives alone and has limited social support. She worked as a high school teacher till 5 years ago  currently retired. She reports no known allergies. Recent laboratory studies revealed mild deterioration in her renal function. This  along with her clinical presentation  suggests the likelihood of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson  a 72-year-old African-American male  presents to the clinic with progressive shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He has a 10-year history of hypertension  is obese with a BMI of 30.2  and a known smoker (1 pack per day for 40 years). He reports symptoms of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and persistent fatigue. He mentions gaining 7 pounds in the past week. He has been adherent to his antihypertensive medication: Hydrochlorothiazide and Lisinopril. Family history is significant as both his father and brother had heart disease. He does not have any prior hospital admissions. On examination  he has elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral pedal edema  and rales in the lungs. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg with a pulse rate of 92 per minute. He is currently employed as a truck driver and lives with his wife.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of increased shortness of breath and fatigue over the past week. He notes that he has gained 5 lbs in the past month  which is unusual for him. He has found it difficult to lie flat due to breathlessness and has been waking up at night gasping for air.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a known history of ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had an acute myocardial infarction approximately four years ago  which was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention. His current medications include metformin  losartan  and aspirin. He has a 45-pack year smoking history but quit five years ago post his myocardial infarction. He admits to occasional alcohol intake and eats a diet high in processed foods and salt. He has been noncompliant with his medications over the last two months due to financial constraints.   Family History:   There is a significant family history of cardiac disorders; both his father and older brother suffered from early-onset coronary artery disease. His mother has hypertension  and his younger sister has type 2 diabetes. There's no documented history of inheritable or congenital heart diseases in the family.  Social History:  Mr. Johnson is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife. He is financially dependent on his retirement savings.    Physical Exam on Presentation:  On examination  Mr. Johnson appears dyspneic and mildly distressed. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  pulse of 98 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Obesity is noted with a BMI of 30 kg/m^2. Lung auscultation is notable for bilateral rales  and cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop. His extremities show 2+ pitting edema bilaterally. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Mr. J. Smith is a 74 year-old Caucasian male presenting with progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  and noticeable weight gain over the past few months. He mentions worsening symptoms over the last week  particularly feeling breathless at rest and finding it difficult to sleep lying flat due to breathlessness. He also reports reduced exercise tolerance and swelling of his ankles.  He has a known medical history of hypertension  managed with lisinopril for the past 10 years  and a 40-pack year history of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago  followed by stent placement. He also reports a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. Family history is significant for heart disease  with his father passing away from a heart attack at age 68. He currently lives with his wife  drinks alcohol occasionally  and does not use illegal substances.   Upon physical examination  he appears in moderate respiratory distress and has pitting edema in his ankles and an elevated jugular venous pressure. Auscultation of the heart reveals a gallop rhythm  and lung examination reveals bibasilar crackles. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation is 94% on room air  and he weighs 102 kg.   This presentation is suggestive of worsening heart failure in the context of significant cardiovascular comorbidity. Further investigations  including lab works and imaging  are needed to confirm the diagnosis and aid in formulating a management plan.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired police officer.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  especially when lying flat  and fatigue over the past several weeks. He has also noticed swelling in his legs and a recent weight gain of approximately 10 pounds.  Past medical history: Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He suffered from a myocardial infarction five years ago  which was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention and placement of a drug-eluting stent in his left anterior descending coronary artery. His current medications include metformin  ramipril  metoprolol  and rosuvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit after his myocardial infarction.   Family history: His father died in his 70s from congestive heart failure and his mother died in her 80s from a cerebrovascular accident.   Social History: Mr. Smith is married  has two adult children  and lives with his wife. He enjoys fishing and watching football. He denies use of illicit drugs. He does not drink alcohol.   On examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse 85 bpm  and his weight is increased by 5 kg compared to his last visit 4 months ago. Respiratory examination reveals bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination is significant for an S3 gallop. Bilateral pitting edema is present in his lower extremities. His EKG shows nonspecific T-wave changes compared to his previous study.   The initial working diagnosis is congestive heart failure  likely due to an ischemic cardiomyopathy given his significant cardiac history. Further evaluation is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and guide the management.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Martha Matthews  a 72-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue  swelling in her lower extremities  and abrupt weight gain of 5 kilograms over the past month. Ms. Matthews reports difficulty breathing  especially when lying flat  accompanied by a persistent  non-productive cough. The patient adds that she has been experiencing diminished appetite and occasional bouts of dizziness and confusion.  Her past medical history reveals she suffered from a myocardial infarction five years ago  for which she underwent angioplasty. She has continued taking antiplatelet agents and statins for risk reduction. Ms. Matthews is also a known type II diabetes patient for the past ten years  meanwhile being on metformin and sitagliptin. She also has a history of hypertension  having received a diagnosis twenty years ago. Her hypertensive medication regimen includes an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and a beta-blocker. She denies-drinking alcohol but affirms a 40-pack-year smoking history and quit only two years ago.   Ms. Matthews’ family history is significant for cardiac diseases; both parents suffered from congestive heart failure  and her elder brother recently underwent a bypass surgery for multi-vessel coronary artery disease.  She retired from a secretarial job ten years ago  and she lives alone. Her immediate family includes two children  both living out of state. She indicates her adherence to her medications is sometimes inconsistent due to the financial constraints.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Sidney White  a 76-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with a significant increase in exertional dyspnea  persistent cough  swelling in his legs and ankles  and unexplained weight gain over the last 2 weeks. He admits he has been feeling unusually tired and has been experiencing a loss of appetite.  Historically  he was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  both of which he manages with oral medications. The patient has had one myocardial infarction five years ago  but declined any surgical intervention at that time due to personal beliefs. He has been a 20-pack year smoker but quit two years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; both parents and one older sibling died of heart disease in their late 60s.   Mr. White lives alone and struggles with medication adherence due to both cognitive and financial constraints. He does not follow a specific diet nor does he exercise regularly  which he attributes to being ""too old and tired"". He does not consume alcohol.  He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin for cardiovascular protection. His last known HbA1c was 7.8% and his most recent blood pressure reading taken by a home health nurse was 150/92 mmHg one week ago. He does not recall the exact details of his cholesterol levels  but he was told they were 'higher than normal' at his last check-up six months ago.   Given the chronicity of his conditions and his recent symptom development  he is likely presenting with congestive heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. George Thomas  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanic  married  with three adult children.  Chief Complaint: ""I have been feeling really weak and tired lately. I've also noticed I have been getting short of breath even when doing simple tasks like climbing stairs or carrying groceries.""  History of Present Illness: He states he has been experiencing these symptoms progressively over the past two months. In addition  he has had some swelling in his ankles. He has not had any chest pain  but has noticed palpitations on a few occasions. His sleep has been affected; he states he wakes up feeling short of breath and needs to sit up to breathe better.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of stage 2 hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. He also has hyperlipidemia and a 40 pack-year history of smoking  but he quit tobacco five years ago. He does not have any known coronary artery disease but had a stress test five years ago that was normal. He does not have any prior surgical history.  Medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily  Metformin 500 mg twice a day  Atorvastatin 10 mg daily.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother has type 2 diabetes and is alive at 90 years old.   Review of Systems: Denies chest pain  cough  or fever. Reports occasional night sweats. No changes in weight. Reports an increase in urination.  Physical Exam: Patient appears fatigued. His blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate 92 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Cardiac exam reveals an S3 sound. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the base of both lungs. There is 2+ bilateral lower limb edema.  Given the patient's symptoms of fatigue  shortness of breath  and bilateral edema  as well as his findings on cardiac examination  there is a clinical suspicion for heart failure. Further diagnostic testing  such as an echocardiogram  will need to be done to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Information: Mr. James Smith  a 68-year-old African-American male  Chief Complaint: Increasing shortness of breath and fatigue for the last three weeks  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith has been experiencing progressive dyspnea on exertion and significant fatigue. The symptoms have been gradually worsening and now he is unable to walk more than half a block without resting due to shortness of breath. He has noted increased leg swelling and has gained five pounds in the past week. He also complains of occasional nocturnal cough and gets up several times in the night to pass urine.   Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago  managed medically with Lisinopril and Amlodipine. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  currently on Metformin. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement.  Social History: He is a retired mechanical engineer. Smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years  quit 10 years ago. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family History: His father died from a stroke and his mother had heart failure. His younger brother is living and has diabetes.  Review of Systems: Positive for orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Negative for chest pain  cough  fever or any gastrointestinal symptoms.  Physical Exam: Mr. Smith is alert and oriented but appears fatigued. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 98 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute. He has a mildly elevated jugular venous pressure and crackles are heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. His abdomen is soft  and there is 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.   Assessment: Given the patient's past medical history and clinical presentation  the working diagnosis is acute decompensated heart failure. Additional investigations will be needed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of his condition.

Patient Information: Mr. John Parker  65-year-old male of Caucasian descent  Chief Complaint: Generalized fatigue  shortness of breath  and swelling in the legs.   History of Present Illness: The symptoms started gradually over the past 3-4 months but have worsened in the past 2 weeks. The dyspnea is mostly exertional  but Mr. Parker reports occasional shortness of breath even at rest.   Past Medical History: He has a known history of ischaemic heart disease  and he suffered a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has been hypertensive for the past 10 years and has type 2 diabetes  diagnosed 8 years ago. He is a former smoker  having stopped 4 years ago following his myocardial infarction. He drinks alcohol only occasionally and doesn't use recreational drugs.  Medications: He takes a daily regimen of metformin  aspirin  a beta-blocker (metoprolol)  and a statin (atorvastatin) for his diabetes  heart disease  and high cholesterol levels.   Family History: Both his father and grandfather died of heart-related issues in their 60s.  Social History: Mr. Parker is retired and lives with his wife. He has two adult children who are healthy. He enjoys playing golf but has been unable to do so recently due to fatigue and breathlessness.  Review of Systems: Negative for fever  chest pain  cough  GI symptoms  and recent weight changes. Positive for dyspnea  orthopnoea  pedal edema  decreased exercise tolerance  frequent nighttime urination and generalized fatigue.   Vital Signs: Blood pressure: 150/90 mmHg; Pulse: 90 bpm; Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/min; Temperature: 37.0 degrees C; Oxygen saturation: 94% on room air; Body Mass Index: 29 (Overweight)  Physical Exam: Patient is alert and oriented. Cardiac examination reveals an S3 gallop and jugular venous distention. Lung auscultation shows crackles at the bases. The abdomen is soft and non-distended  with no hepatosplenomegaly. There is 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the knees.   Given the symptoms and his past medical history  there is a high suspicion of heart failure. Further diagnostic tests  including blood tests for renal function  liver function  thyroid function  and a BNP level  as well as an EKG and echocardiogram  will be needed to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the degree of cardiac dysfunction.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Lynne Simon is a 72-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the clinic complaining of increased shortness of breath over the past week  especially during activities that previously did not strain her  like climbing a flight of stairs or walking for more than 15 minutes. She also reports swelling in her ankles and feet that worsens throughout the day and mild but persistent fatigue.      Clinical History:  Ms. Simon has a documented history of diabetes mellitus type II  manages her condition with metformin  and has generally good glycemic control. She was diagnosed with hypertension approximately ten years ago and takes lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide daily for management. She had an episode of non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) two years back and subsequently underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to her left anterior descending artery. She has been compliant with her medications  which include daily aspirin and atorvastatin.   Ms. Simon has been a non-smoker her entire life and denies any illicit drug use. She consumes alcohol occasionally  rarely exceeding one drink per week. Her father passed away from congestive heart failure at 76 years of age  and her mother had a stroke at the age of 83 years. She has one older brother who has been recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.   Her general physical exam reveals bilateral pedal edema and crackles in her lower lung fields. Her BMI is within normal range and her blood pressure is slightly elevated despite medication.   Given the combination of her symptoms  findings  and her past medical history  there is a strong suspicion that Ms. Simon may be presenting with heart failure. Further diagnostic testing including echocardiography and blood tests are planned for confirmation.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male  presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea over the past two months. He reports needing four pillows to sleep at night and not being able to walk more than half a mile without needing to rest. He also complains of increasing lower limb edema and recently noticed rapid weight gain. Family history is significant for diseases of the cardiovascular system.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension that has been controlled with Lisinopril for the past decade. He has a 20-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well managed with Metformin. He is also a smoker with 40 pack-years and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Physical Examination: Mr. Doe appears dyspneic but not in acute distress. His BMI is 28. On cardiac examination  a laterally displaced apical impulse  S3 gallop  and jugular vein distention are noted. His lung fields show crackles bilaterally. Palpable swelling and pitting edema can be seen up to his knees bilaterally.  Investigations: Laboratory tests including complete blood count  comprehensive metabolic panel  B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP)  and thyroid function tests are suggested. Further investigations may include Chest X-Rays  Electrocardiogram (ECG) and Echo-cardiogram.   Clinical Impression: The presentation  physical examination and patient's medical history are consistent with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF)  possibly as a result of long-standing hypertension  diabetes  and lifestyle factors.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Richard Smith is a 65-year-old African-American male  who presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath  persistent cough  rapid weight gain and intense fatigue over the past two weeks. He reports difficulty in performing routine tasks such as walking short distances without getting tired or dyspneic.  He denies any chest pain or syncope episodes but does mention some nocturia and pedal edema. He also reports easy fatigability and loss of appetite with moderate amount of orthopnea.  Past Medical History reveals a diagnosis of hypertension for the last 10 years  which he says is 'mostly' controlled with daily medication (Lisinopril). He also has Type 2 diabetes that is managed with diet and metformin. Mr. Smith has a history of moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and had acute myocardial infarction three years back.   He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day but claims that he has quit since his heart attack. He admits to occasional alcohol and denies any illicit drug use. There is a family history of early cardiac disease with his father passing away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 50.  On physical examination  Mr. Smith appears dyspneic even at rest. Vitals reveal BP of 140/90  HR of 100 and RR of 25. Cardiovascular examination revealed an S3 heart sound and there are signs of 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Lung auscultation suggests bibasilar crackles. Rest of the exam is unremarkable. This clinical picture is suggestive of congestive heart failure. Further tests including chest radiography  ECG and echocardiography are planned for definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of increased shortness of breath  fatigue  and swelling in his legs and ankles over the past two weeks. The patient reports that he has been waking up in the middle of the night due to difficulty breathing and has to prop his head up on multiple pillows to get comfortable. He also notes his shoes fitting more tightly than usual due to the swelling.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension and a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 60. He is currently on the following medications: aspirin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. Despite a moderate salt-reduced diet and medication  the patient's hypertension is still not well-controlled. He does not exercise regularly citing fatigue as the main hindrance.   There is no history of alcohol or substance abuse. Previous investigations revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 45% and elevated BNP levels. His most recent blood pressure reading was 160/90 mmHg  and BMI was recorded as 30  suggesting obesity.   These symptoms  in addition to his demographic details and past medical history  suggest that Mr. Jones may be experiencing heart failure.

Patient Information: A 72-year-old African American male.  Chief Complaint: Progressive shortness of breath on exertion and swelling in his lower extremities over the past two weeks.  History of Present Illness: The patient has noticed increasing difficulty in walking short distances and climbing stairs due to breathlessness. He also mentions waking up in the middle of the night gasping for breath. He noticed increased swelling in his feet and ankles. He has occasional bouts of cough  especially when lying flat  and also reports orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. His weight has increased by 4kg over the past week. No chest pain  palpitations  or dizziness reported.   Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  for which he takes amlodipine 5mg daily. He was a chronic smoker until 7 years ago and has a history of alcohol use. He has a known history of Diabetes Mellitus  Type 2 for the past 10 years managed with oral hypoglycemic drugs.   Family History: Father died of a heart attack at 65  mother has hypertension.  Review of Systems: Reports chronic fatigue. Denies chest pain but has reduced appetite. Urine output is reduced.   Physical Examination: On general examination  he is noted to be short of breath. His blood pressure is elevated at 155/95 mmHg. Irregular pulse at 92 beats per minute. Bilateral rales on lung auscultation are noted. Heart sounds show S3 gallop. There is conspicuous venous distension in his neck. Lower extremities exhibit 2+ pitting edema. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged heart shadow and signs of pulmonary congestion.   Differential Diagnoses: Heart failure  kidney failure  liver disease.  This patient's symptoms  history  and physical examination are most suggestive of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African-American male with a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic smoke of 30 pack-years. He presents to the clinic with a history of progressive shortness of breath over the last month. He reports that his difficulty breathing is worse during night when lying flat  to the degree that he has been propping himself up to sleep. He also reports significant fatigue and swelling in his feet and ankles that gets worse throughout the day  making it difficult to put on his shoes. Mr. Johnson also describes a recent unintended weight gain of approximately 5 pounds over the last week. On further questioning  he mentions that he had been less compliant with his usual medications  including his anti-hypertensive drugs and insulin  over the last month. He denies any history of chest pain  palpitations  or pre-syncope/syncope. He also notes that he’s found it increasingly difficult to climb stairs due to extreme tiredness. His day-to-day activities are significantly limited.  He lives alone  retired  was previously a pipefitter  and is widowed with 3 adult children who live out of state. His father died at age 78 of a heart attack and his mother died at age 84 of unknown reasons. He is a past smoker  having quit 10 years back  and describes his 30-pack years of smoking. He consumes alcohol rarely and denies recreational drug use. Has been adhering to dietary restrictions for diabetes.  On examination  he appears fatigued and in mild distress due to breathing difficulty. Findings include jugular venous distention  bilateral fine rales on lung auscultation  hepatomegaly on abdominal palpation  and bilateral pitting edema on lower extremity examination. His cardiac exam reveals a third heart sound.  This patient's clinical features  physical exam findings  and past medical and social histories are suggestive of decompensated heart failure.

Patient Information: Ms. Rodriguez  68-year-old Hispanic female   Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath  easy fatigue  and leg swelling  History of Present Illness: Ms. Rodriguez reports a 2 month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  especially when she attempts light activities like walking or climbing stairs. She also reports frequent night time awakening due to breathlessness. She has noticed swelling in her legs  typically worse at the end of the day and mild  unexplained weight gain over the same time period.  Relevant Past Medical History: She has a significant history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago. She had an episode of acute myocardial infarction 5 years ago followed by an angioplasty.  Social History: Current smoker  smoking for 40 years  15 cigarettes per day. She denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. She lives alone and retired from teaching 6 years ago.  Family History: Mother died at the age of 60 from a heart attack. Father died at the age of 75 from complications related to stroke. She has an older brother who is living with coronary artery disease.   Medication History: She is currently taking Metformin for diabetes  Aspirin  and a beta-blocker post her myocardial infarction  and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension.  Review of Systems: She denies any chest pain  palpitations  cough  or fever. There is no symptom of thyroid disease  stroke  or kidney disease. No history of rheumatic fever or previous cardiomyopathy.  Physical Examination: Patient appears dyspneic on minimal exertion. On cardiovascular examination  S3 gallop and jugular venous distension are noted. Breath sounds are decreased at lung bases & there are crackles half way up both lung fields. Her lower limbs show 2+ pitting edema up to her knees.   Assessment: Clinical features suggest congestive heart failure. Recommend ECG  echo  CBC  BMP  liver function tests  B-type natriuretic peptide  chest radiograph  and cardiac stress testing to further evaluate her condition. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further management.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old African American male who presents with a 1-week history of fatigue  shortness of breath  and swollen legs. The patient reports that he has had a persistent dry cough and has noticed he has been gaining weight  despite not changing his eating habits.    He is a retired truck driver  and lives with his wife. He has a 35 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use.  In his medical history  the patient has had hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 20 years  which has been managed with antihypertensive medications and Metformin. He reports poor adherence to his medications  and his blood glucose levels and blood pressure have been poorly controlled.  He's also had a myocardial infarction five years prior and underwent a successful angioplasty at that time.  Family history is significant for heart disease  with his father having died of congestive heart failure at the age of 72.  On examination  the patient appears short of breath at rest. Chest is clear to auscultation  but a decreased air entry is reported at the bases. Cardiac examination demonstrates a S3 heart sound. There is pitting edema present in both lower extremities up to the level of the shins.  An ECG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy. No other significant findings in physical examination.  Given his presentation  and past medical history  the working diagnosis of congestive heart failure is made. The patient is admitted for further management and investigation.

Patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. John Doe  who presents with a complaint of increasing shortness of breath over the last two weeks. He mentions that the breathlessness is worse upon exertion and when lying flat. He also complains of swelling in both lower limbs  and a gradual weight gain over the past month.  His past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension for 10 years  2 previous myocardial infarctions (5 years and 2 years ago)  stable angina  and type 2 diabetes mellitus.   He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  and he admits to moderate alcohol consumption. Family history reveals coronary artery disease in both parents and one sibling with heart failure.   The patient is currently on aspirin  amlodipine  metformin  and a statin. He is adherent to his medications and follows up regularly for his conditions.   On examination  the patient appears breathless with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 92 bpm. Lower limb edema is present up to the mid-shins bilaterally. He has displacement of the apex beat and bibasilar lung crackles.   The rest of the examination is unremarkable. From the history  examination  and past medical records  the clinical picture is highly suggestive of congestive heart failure.

Patient's Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  non-smoker  living in downtown New York.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with worsening shortness of breath over the past two months  associated with fatigue  swelling in the legs  and mild chest pain under exertion.  History of Present Illness: Previously  he was able to walk 1 mile without difficulty but now becomes dyspneic after just 100 yards. Swelling in his legs has increased over the past two weeks and progressively worsened by the end of the day. He has been waking up at night gasping for breath  using several pillows to sleep. No associated cough  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He notes that his shoes feel tight.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  managed with Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  controlled with Metformin. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  followed by percutaneous coronary intervention and stent placement in the left anterior descending artery.  Family History: Father died from a stroke at 80 years old; Mother suffers from arthritis. His brother has Type II Diabetes and sister has hypertension.  Social History: Retired engineer  married with 3 adult children. Lives with his wife. Non-smoker. Drinks alcohol socially  twice a week. Denies recreational drug use.   Review of Systems: Denies symptoms of fever  weight loss  change in appetite  or any other systemic symptoms.  Physical Examination: Vital signs show Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg  pulse: 100 bpm  regular  respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation: 92% on room air. BMI: 28 kg/m2. Mild pallor is present. Jugular venous distention is observed. Auscultation reveals an S3 heart sound  decreased breath sounds at lung bases bilaterally. Swelling and pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities up to mid-calf is noted. No cyanosis  clubbing  or lymphadenopathy.  Impression: Findings are consistent with heart failure  likely systolic dysfunction considering the patient's history of myocardial infarction. He is currently in New York Heart Association Functional Class III. Immediate referral to a cardiologist is recommended for medical optimization and a possible echocardiogram for a more thorough evaluation of heart function. Further management will rely on specialist advice.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jack Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of progressive shortness of breath  exercise intolerance  and edema in the lower extremities for the past two weeks. He reports a chronic cough that is worse at night and a significant weight gain (approximately 5 kg) in the past two months.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a known history of ischemic heart disease with a myocardial infarction occurring five years ago  for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes Metformin 500 mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10 mg once daily  and Rosuvastatin 20 mg once daily  respectively.   Social History:   Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  a nonsmoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife  and they have three adult children who live in the vicinity.   Review of Systems:  Mr. Smith denies chest pain or palpitations but reports experiencing increased fatigue and poor appetite  along with increased urination at night.  Exam Findings:   Physical examination shows an alert  oriented and mildly distressed patient due to dyspnea. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 132/88 mm Hg  pulse 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Auscultation reveals bibasilar rales in his lungs and an S3 heart sound. There is jugular venous distention along with 2+ pitting edema extending up to the shins bilaterally.   Given Mr. Smith's current condition and his past medical history  the diagnosis of heart failure is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting to the clinic with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and swelling in his ankles. He reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past 6 months. Recently  he's noticed he's waking up at night due to breathlessness and is currently using three pillows to sleep. Activity level has declined as well due to a decrease in energy and needing to rest after minimal exertion. No chest pain  palpitations or syncope was noted. He also reports unintended weight gain of 5 lbs in the last week.   Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type 2 diabetes managed with hydrochlorothiazide and metformin respectively. He is a former smoker and gave up the habit 10 years back. His family history reveals that his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 74.   On physical examination  he appears dyspneic with noted peripheral pitting edema up to the mid-shins. He has elevated jugular venous pressure and on auscultation  there is an S3 heart sound and crackles at both lung bases  suggestive of cardiac failure.   This history is strongly indicative of congestive heart failure  requiring urgent evaluation and management after confirmation with diagnostic tests including bloodwork for BNP levels  kidney function  liver function and a chest X-ray and echocardiography.

Patient Information: Mr. James Williams  a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Progressive shortness of breath  leg swelling and fatigue over the past 3 months.  Present Illness: Patient reports increasing difficulty in completing routine activities due to breathlessness. His shortness of breath is more pronounced at night and when he lies flat. He also notes bilateral leg swelling and unexplained recent weight gain of about 7lbs. His symptoms are relieved by rest and when propping up with pillows at night.  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which he has been managing with prescribed medications for the past 10 years. He was diagnosed with myocardial infarction 5 years ago.  Medication: Patient takes Metoprolol  Lisinopril  Aspirin  and Metformin.  Family Medical History: Father had coronary artery disease and passed away due to myocardial infarction at age 74. Mother is alive with hypertension. One sister with type 2 diabetes.  Social History: Patient is a former smoker  quit 5 years ago after the diagnosis of myocardial infarction. He admits to occasional alcohol use and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He worked as a truck driver for over 30 years and recently retired.  Physical Examination: Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. He is in mild respiratory distress and has to stop a few times to catch his breath during the conversation. Examination reveals bilateral lower extremity edema  jugular venous distension  and bibasilar rales in lungs. Heart sounds reveal an S3 gallop.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  comes into our office feeling weak and lethargic. He reports experiencing shortness of breath  particularly at night time  when he lays flat on his bed. He also mentions that he has to sleep with multiple pillows to catch his breath. Additionally  he has been noticing swelling in his ankles and feet which gets worse by evening and seems to be progressively increasing over the past week. He also reports unexplained weight gain.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a past medical history that includes hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and was subsequently diagnosed with ischemic cardiomyopathy. His medications include Metoprolol  Lisinopril  and Metformin. He also has a history of smoking for 30 years  but quit 5 years ago  and he reports occasional alcohol intake. He lives alone in a two-story house and reports that he has recently been struggling more than usual with climbing the stairs to his bedroom.   Family History:   His father died of a heart attack at age 65  and his mother has hypertension. Both his older brother and his sister have high cholesterol.   Review of Systems:   Mr. Doe denies any chest pain  dizziness  loss of consciousness  palpitations  cough  or recent changes in bowel or urinary habits. He has though noticed reduced appetite.   Physical Examination:   On examination  Mr. Doe appears visibly fatigued. He has bilateral pitting edema up to his mid-shins. Signs of pulmonary congestion (rales) are heard on auscultation. His jugular veins are distended. He has increased heart rate (tachycardia) and a third heart sound (S3 gallop) upon cardiac examination. His blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg.  Given Mr. Doe's past medical history of ischemic heart disease and his presenting symptoms  a provisional diagnosis of congestive heart failure is considered. Further diagnostic evaluations such as ECG  chest x-ray  and echocardiogram are planned to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate his condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and weight gain over the past few weeks. He describes reduced exercise tolerance  having to stop and rest following minimal exertion  and reports that he has trouble sleeping flat at night due to difficulty breathing. He adds that he requires more pillows just to get comfortable.   Mr. Doe has also noticed that his ankles and legs seem swollen by the end of the day  and he feels his shoes are tighter than usual. On further questioning  he states he's been experiencing some stomach bloating and reduced appetite as well. Over the last month  he has gained approximately 7 pounds.  Relevant Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe is diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which he manages with Lisinopril 10 mg daily  Metformin 500 mg twice daily  and periodic insulin use. He had a myocardial infarction around eight years ago  which was managed with angioplasty. He is a former smoker  quitting ten years ago following his heart attack  but he admits to a heavy smoking history prior to that – about 20 cigarettes a day for more than 30 years. He continues to drink alcohol occasionally  about 2-3 drinks per week.   Mr. Doe has a family history significant for heart disease; both his father and older brother died of heart attacks in their early 70s. He lives with his wife  is retired  and is generally active in his community. His last assessment blood pressure was recorded at 140/90 mmHg  and his most recent HbA1c was 7.5%.  These symptoms  along with his preferences of lifestyle and significant past medical history  suggest an exacerbation of chronic heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department complaining of increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and noticeable weight gain over the past two weeks. He reports difficulty breathing when lying flat and requires three pillows for adequate relief  indicating orthopnea. He additionally states that he has been waking up in the middle of the night gasping for air  which indicates paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. Mr. Doe has a 20-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  reports a diet high in sodium content  and admits to moderate alcohol use. He admits to missing doses of his home medications frequently  which include Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril and Metoprolol for his hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his high cholesterol.   His family history is significant for his father passing away from myocardial infarction at age 68  and his mother has chronic heart failure. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  dizziness  or palpitations. Despite his symptoms  Mr. Doe’s spirit remains high and he has a supportive family who accompanies him for his visit. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention  bilateral rales on lung auscultation and 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. His blood pressure is 160/90  pulse 98  temperature 98.6 F  respiratory rate 22  and oxygen saturation 90% on room air.  Given his symptoms  clinical presentation  and medical history  Mr. Doe is suspected to be experiencing acute decompensated heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old African American male  retired engineer.  Chief Complaint: Progressive Shortness of breath  fatigue and ankle swelling  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith presents with complaints of increasing shortness of breath over the past several months  particularly during physical exertion and at night. He says that he has trouble sleeping flat and usually uses three pillows to prop himself up. He reports having bouts of extreme fatigue periodically over the same timeframe. Recently  he has also noted swelling in his ankles  which seems to worsen at night.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of:  1) Hypertension  diagnosed ten years ago  managed with Lisinopril 2) Type 2 Diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 5 years ago  on Metformin 3) Previous myocardial infarction (heart attack) 2 years ago  Family History: His mother passed away in her late 70s due to heart failure  father deceased from an accident  brother living with type 2 diabetes  and sister living with no serious issues.  Social History: Lifelong non-smoker  occasional alcohol usage  exercises irregularly due to his recent symptoms.  Medications: Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes.   Review of Systems: No significant weight gain  no chest pain  no complaints of palpitations or dizziness  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable  JVP elevated  lungs clear to auscultation  heart sounds reveal a third heart sound (S3) with no murmurs. There is 2+ bilateral pitting edema on both ankles. He has a body mass index of 30.   This is a classic presentation of heart failure  likely systolic  given the history of myocardial infarction  diabetes  and hypertension. Mr. Smith's symptoms of shortness of breath  orthopnea  fatigue  and ankle swelling suggest worsening heart failure. His clearly elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) and the presence of an S3 further increase the suspicion for heart failure. Further diagnostic tests  including echocardiography and laboratory tests  should be ordered to establish the diagnosis and assess the severity of heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old African American male who is presenting to the outpatient cardiology clinic with symptoms of increasing shortness of breath and edema in the lower extremities. Over the past few weeks  Mr. Jones has noticed difficulty in simple activities such as walking to his mailbox or climbing the stairs in his home. Additionally  he describes experiencing progressive swelling in his ankles and feet  particularly in the evenings. He denies experiencing any chest pain  dizziness  or changes in his weight.  Relevant Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  non-insulin dependent type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  and a 30-pack year history of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. He has never been diagnosed with heart disease  but his father passed away at age 70 from a heart attack. Mr. Jones has no known drug allergies. He is currently taking metformin for his diabetes  lisinopril for his hypertension  and a daily aspirin.   He lives with his wife  has two adult children  and was formerly a bus driver but is currently retired. He has limited physical activity due to arthritis in his knees and has a diet that is moderately high in salt. His alcohol intake is moderate  and he denies illicit drug use.   His presenting signs and past medical history  including hypertension  diabetes  and prior smoking  place Mr. Jones at an increased risk for heart failure. Further assessment and diagnostic testing will be required to confirm this suspected diagnosis.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  68-year-old Caucasian male.   Chief Complaint:  Progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  swelling in lower extremities over past few weeks.   History of Present Illness:  The patient describes experiencing an increasing difficulty in breathing  particularly when laying flat (orthopnea)  and exerting himself. He notes marked swelling in his ankles and feet (edema) and mentions feeling tired more than usual. He also states that he has been waking up at night due to breathlessness (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). He denies chest pain  cough  or recent illness.   Past Medical History:  He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are controlled with medication. He also has a history of coronary artery disease for which he underwent angioplasty 3 years ago.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's father passed away at the age of 72 from what he believes was a “heart-related disease” and his 75-year-old sister has a history of high blood pressure.  Social History:  Retired truck driver  married with 3 adult children. He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 30 pack-year history prior. Occasional alcohol use  denies illicit drug use.   Medication History:   Metformin 1000mg twice a day  lisinopril 10mg once a day  hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg once a day  and aspirin 81mg once a day.   Review of Systems:  No other significant symptoms reported. He has no complaints of chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or palpitations.  Physical Exam:  Moderate pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities up to mid-shin. Jugular venous distension noted. Heart sounds are normal but distant. There are crackles on bilateral lung bases on auscultation  consistent with pulmonary congestion.   Based on the clinical presentation  a diagnosis of heart failure is suspected. Further laboratory tests  chest X-ray  and an echocardiogram will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. Allen  a 68-year-old African-American male.  Chief Complaint: Increasing shortness of breath and swelling in his lower extremities over the past few weeks.   Patient History: Patient has a known past medical history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  type II diabetes mellitus  and a previous myocardial infarction approximately 2 years ago. He continues to be a 20-pack year smoker  despite tobacco cessation education and prior attempts to quit.  Symptoms: He reports symptoms including fatigue after moderate activity  increasing abdominal girth  persistent cough often worse at night  and trouble sleeping unless propped up by pillows. The patient also noticed a recent weight gain of about 5 pounds within the past week.  Physical Exam: On examination  the patient appears dyspneic at rest with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse 88  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air.  He exhibits jugular venous distention and faint S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation. Pulmonary exam reveals bibasilar crackles  and the lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema up to the knee.  Treatment history: He is currently on a medication regimen of aspirin  metoprolol  lisinopril  and atorvastatin for his hypertension and coronary artery disease. He uses insulin for his diabetes management.   Family history: His father died of a heart attack in his 70s  and mother has been diagnosed with heart failure in her 80s. Both his siblings have hypertension.  Risk factors: Poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes  continued smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and high-salt diet. High cholesterol and family history of cardiovascular diseases also increase his risk.  Based on the patient's symptoms  physical exam findings  medical history  and risk factors  a preliminary diagnosis of decompensated heart failure can be considered. Likely actions would include adjustment in medications  urgent lifestyle modifications and  if necessary  consideration for more advanced treatments or referral to a cardiovascular specialist.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath and swelling in his ankles that has developed over the last several weeks. The patient also reports experiencing frequent nocturia as well as poor appetite.   Demographics:   The patient is a retired construction worker  married with two children. He lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a current smoker with a 40-pack year history. He admits to occasional alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use.  Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily for the past 10 years. The patient also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with Metformin 1000mg twice a day. He had a myocardial infarction approximately five years ago  for which he underwent a successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with placement of a drug-eluting stent.  Family History:  The patient’s father died at the age of 58 due to heart disease  and his mother had hypertension and passed away at the age of 68 from complications related to stroke.    Social History:  The patient reports that he is a retired construction worker  currently living with his wife. He is a heavy smoker with a history of 40 pack years. He also admits to drinking alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug use.

Patient Information: 67-year old African-American male   Chief Complaint: Increased fatigue  shortness of breath upon exertion  and worsening lower limb swelling.  Present Illness: The patient reports that over the past month  he has experienced a gradual increase in fatigue and shortness of breath  especially when he climbs stairs or walks for more than a few minutes. He also reports a notable increase in the swelling of his lower limbs  which has become more severe over the past week. His symptoms have become increasingly bothersome and interfere with his daily activities  particularly his ability to walk his dog.  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both being controlled through medication. He also reports a prior myocardial infarction 7 years ago. The patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack history  but he quit smoking after his myocardial infarction. He is also a non-drinker.  Medication: The patient is on Metformin (for type 2 diabetes)  Lisinopril and low-dose aspirin (for hypertension and post-myocardial infarction management  respectively).   Family History: His father had a history of chronic heart disease and died at the age of 79  and his mother died at the age of 82 due to stroke complications.   Social History: He lives with his wife in a suburban area. He is a retired school teacher and generally leads a sedentary lifestyle. He reports no current or past alcohol or illicit drug use.    Physician's Notes: Exhibits symptoms and signs consistent with congestive heart failure  possibly related to his history of MI  hypertension  and diabetes  all of which are risk factors. Further diagnostic tests are required to confirm diagnosis and assess the severity and possible causes.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history significant for ischemic heart disease  uncontrolled hypertension  and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic.  Chief Complaint: The he patient complains of worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and difficulty in performing usual activities over the last two weeks. He also reports experiencing orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and bilateral lower extremity swelling.   History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith noticed that his shortness of breath worsened after climbing a flight of stairs two weeks ago and now he becomes breathless after talking for a prolonged period. His fatigue has made it hard for him to complete everyday tasks like cooking or showering. He also reports gaining 5 pounds in the last week.   Past Medical History: His high blood pressure has remained uncontrolled despite taking Atenolol 50mg daily for the past 10 years. His diabetes has been managed with Metformin 1000mg twice daily and his most recent HbA1c was 7.2%. He had a single episode of chest pain about 3 years ago  which was diagnosed as an acute myocardial infarction  and he had a stent placed at that time. He also has moderate renal impairment (eGFR 40ml/minute)  which was diagnosed 5 years ago. He also had a smoking history of 30 pack years but quit smoking following his heart attack.  Review of systems: The patient declines any chest pain  palpitations  lightheadedness  nausea  or vomiting. He is afebrile  denies any recent infections or travel history. No history of recent trauma  bleeding  or blood clots. Denies any changes in urinary and bowel habits. No cognitive or mood disturbances. Denies any allergies.  Medications: His current medications include Atenolol  Metformin  aspirin  clopidogrel  rosuvastatin  and lisinopril. He is compliant with all his medications.  Social History: He is retired  lives with his wife  and has three grown-up children. He quit smoking three years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol  about 2-3 standard drinks per week.   Family History: His mother had hypertension and she passed away at the age of 80 due to stroke. His father had type 2 diabetes and ischemic heart disease  passing away at 75 years of age.   Physical Examination: His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation in room air is 95% and he is afebrile. The cardiovascular examination reveals an S3 gallop rhythm. His lungs are clear to auscultation. His abdomen is soft  non-tender but distended. His lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema up to the level of the knees. His neurological examination is unremarkable.   The patient appears to be suffering from heart failure  possibly related to a long history of poorly controlled hypertension  diabetes  and previous myocardial infarction. Further evaluation including chest x-ray  ECG  echocardiography and blood tests (including BNP) are advised for him.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 68-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic with the chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath and generalized fatigue for the past couple of months. He also reports a gradual weight gain of about 10-15 pounds over the past 3 months  along with ankle swelling that worsens throughout the day.   Regarding his medical history  he has a 20-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are managed with Metoprolol and Metformin respectively. He is also suffering from moderate obese since his late 40s. He stopped smoking 10 years ago  and admits to occasional alcohol use. His father had a myocardial infarction in his 70s and his mother had chronic kidney disease.   He underwent coronary angiography 5 years ago  revealing moderate stenosis in his left anterior descending artery which was managed with medical therapy. He does not participate in regular exercise due to his chronic knee pain. His current medications include Metoprolol  Metformin  Aspirin  Amlodipine  and Atorvastatin. His is allergic to Sulfa drugs which cause him a rash whenever used. He lives alone  retired  and has a home care nurse visiting him twice a week.

Patient Information: Mr. George Thompson  a 72-year-old African American male and retired construction worker  presents with shortness of breath  persistent coughing and wheezing and fatigue.  Chief complaint: He reports getting progressively worse over the past two months. He is especially breathless with ordinary daily activities (dressing  bathing  very mild activity) that he could easily do before.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Thompson has noticed increased weight gain over the past month despite not eating more. He is experiencing pitting edema in lower extremities  and frequent nocturia. His symptoms are disrupting his sleep quality  requiring him to sit upright most nights to relieve respiratory discomfort.  Past Medical History: He has a 10-year history of hypertension  5 years of type 2 diabetes  and a major myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He was a heavy smoker and has mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  but quit smoking after his heart attack.  Family History: Both of his parents suffered from hypertension  and his father also had a heart attack at age 68.  Social History: He is a widower for the last seven years and lives alone. He has two grown-up children  but they live far away. He admits to drinking 1-2 glasses of wine weekly.  Current Medications: Lisinopril  metformin  aspirin  and a statin.   Given the patient's history  presenting symptoms  and physical exam  he appears to have worsening heart failure.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old African American male who has presented to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath  worsening fatigue  and leg swelling over the past week. He reports a weight gain of eight pounds within this time period. He also complains of orthopnea  needing to sleep with three pillows to breathe comfortably. There's also a report of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  waking up from sleep gasping for air  which he relieves by sitting upright. He denies chest pain  palpitation  or dizziness.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril/Hydrochlorothiazide. He had an ischemic stroke five years ago with minimal residual weakness of the right upper arm. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history and quit smoking after the stroke. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 72 bpm  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Jugular venous distension and bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities up to the knees are noted. Auscultation of the chest reveals bibasilar crackles and a S3 gallop. Cardiac examination reveals a displaced left ventricular apical impulse.  Initial investigations including complete blood count  electrolyte panel  and liver function tests are within normal limits. B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is elevated  850 pg/mL. An electrocardiogram demonstrates signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. Further diagnostic workup - an echocardiogram - is being arranged  but the presentation is strongly suggestive of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction given the combination of symptoms  signs  and elevated BNP.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired banker. He has presented with complaints of gradual  worsening shortness of breath over the past six months  particularly with exertion and when lying flat  prompting him to sleep with 3 pillows. He also reports swelling in both his ankles and a gradual increase in abdominal girth  despite a slight decrease in appetite. He claims to have been feeling exceptionally fatigued and weak  finding it hard to engage in activities of daily living.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of ischemic heart disease  with a myocardial infarction experienced thirteen years ago. He has been hypertensive for the last twenty years  poorly controlled at times. Besides  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus eight years ago  for which he has been on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been a heavy smoker for forty years  although he quit five years ago on doctors’ advice. The patient's father died of a sudden cardiac arrest in his sixties and his mother passed away from a stroke in her seventies.  Medication:  Aspirin 75mg daily  Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  and Atorvastatin 20mg at night.  Social History:  He lives alone after the death of his wife three years ago. His daughter visits him weekly. He does not consume alcohol and quit smoking five years ago.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he demonstrates raised jugular venous pressure and bilateral pitting pedal oedema up to the mid-shins. Auscultation of the chest finds crepitations at both lung bases and the heart sounds reveal a 3rd heart sound present. His blood pressure is 140/90mmHg and pulse rate is 89 beats/minute. BMI calculated at 27.6 kg/m².   This patient presentation is suggestive of Congestive Heart Failure.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jane Doe is a 68-year-old African-American female presenting to the office with complaints of gradually worsening exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  and lower extremity edema over the last two months. The patient also reports occasional dry cough and recent reduced exercise tolerance. She denies any chest pain  fever  palpitations  or syncope.  Relevant past medical history includes hypertension  controlled with amlodipine  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin. She has a former smoking history of 10 pack-years  quit 12 years ago. Her father passed away from myocardial infarction at an age of 58  and her mother is living at 88 years of age with Alzheimer's disease. The patient has a surgical history of bilateral knee replacement and a hysterectomy. No known drug allergies have been reported. She is a retired school teacher living with her 70-year-old husband. She consumes alcohol socially with no history of illicit drug use. Her last hospitalization was 12 years ago for her hysterectomy.  This patient's symptoms  together with the past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and smoking  suggest heart failure as a potential diagnosis.

Patient Information: Mr. John Thompson  65-year-old Caucasian male.   Presenting problem: Mr. Thompson came to the ER with complaints about increasing shortness of breath especially while lying flat (orthopnea)  fatigue and bloating of the abdomen over the last 2 weeks. Patient also reported a decrease in appetite and weight gain about 5 kg in the last month.  Vital Signs: BP 160/90 mmHg  HR: 108 bpm  irregular  RR: 24 breaths per minute  Temp: 98.6 F  Oxygen saturation: 88% on room air.
