Mr. Smith reports recent unintentional weight gain and his physical exam reveals jugular venous distention  bilateral crackles in the lower lung field  and a S3 gallop on auscultation. His echocardiogram showing a diminished left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% with changes suggesting dilated cardiomyopathy  suggestive of heart failure. His B-type natriuretic peptide levels are elevated. He has no known allergies  and currently  he is on Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension. His primary caretaker is his wife who assists with medication management and primary care appointments. He is a retired construction worker. He is non-alcoholic  but has a history of smoking.

Patient  a 70-year-old African American male  comes in reporting worsening shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  and recently developed swelling in ankles and legs. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes for which he has been on treatment for 10 years. He is also a former smoker and quit around 5 years ago  after a smoking career of 30 years. He reports he had been managing his symptoms but they have progressively been getting worse over the last two months. His activities of daily living have been severely affected: he is experiencing difficulty walking short distances and needs to sleep in a propped up position as breathing while lying on the bed has become difficult. Additionally  the patient states that he has been gaining weight recently  unsigned. There is no report of chest pain. History reveals no drug nor food allergies. There is no history of similar symptoms in the family. He is retired and lives with his wife. The patient's symptomology is suggestive of heart failure.

Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old African American male  retired banker  presents with a 2 week history of fatigue and increasing shortness of breath during daily activities. He reports occasional episodes of nocturnal dyspnea and recently noticed some swelling in his ankles. There's no history of chest pain or palpitations. The patient has a 10 year history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago.  Relevant past medical history includes a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 for which he underwent a successful angioplasty. The patient is a non-smoker and alcohol intake is minimal. He is compliant with his prescribed medications including metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and clopidogrel for cardiac health.  Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure  a displaced apex beat  bilateral pitting oedema at the ankles up to mid-calf  and some fine bibasal crackling on lung auscultation. Blood pressure is controlled at 130/80 mmHg and heart rate is 90 beats/min at rest. The ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 29.1 kg/m2.  The patient's symptoms of exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  and bilateral pedal edema  along with physical findings and history of cardiac disease  make heart failure a likely diagnosis. Further diagnostic modalities including echocardiography and natriuretic peptide levels are needed to confirm the diagnosis and to assess severity.

Patient Profile: Mr. Jones  a 72-year-old African-American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents to the emergency department.  Medical History: Mr. Jones has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are managed by medication. His blood pressure has been somewhat labile over the past year. He also has hyperlipidemia controlled with statins.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Jones reports experiencing increased shortness of breath over the course of the past two weeks especially when lying flat requiring him to sleep on two pillows (orthopnea)  fatigue  decreased exercise tolerance  and swelling in his ankles (peripheral edema) over the last week. In addition  he reports a weight gain of approximately 5 pounds during the past week. His wife also noticed that he has been seeming more confused than usual. On examination  his blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. There is elevated jugular venous pressure  irregular heartbeat  bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields on auscultation  and pitting edema in both lower extremities. These history and physical examination findings are suspicious for acute decompensated heart failure.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Ramirez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a 40 pack-year smoking history.   Presentation: Mr. Ramirez presents with worsening shortness of breath  fatigued more often than usual over the past two weeks  waking up panting in the middle of the night and increased lower extremity edema.   Symptoms: His symptoms are most severe when he attempts to climb stairs or other mild exertion that had previously not posed problems for him. He also reports a sudden weight gain of 10 pounds over a week  reduced urine output  and nocturia.  Relevant History:  He has been managed with metformin for his diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. He attempted to quit smoking multiple times but restarted due to heavy cravings. He has no known allergies. He states compliance with his medication but admits to a diet high in sodium. There are no other known drug habits. His family history includes a father who died of a ""heart issue"" in his 70s  and a mother who is alive and well.   These symptoms in the context of his past medical history suggest decompensated heart failure. This patient's presentation is likely due to exacerbation of underlying chronic heart failure precipitating from sodium overload in his diet  poor glycemic control  inadequate blood pressure control or his continued smoking habit. It is also possible that he may have had an unobserved myocardial infarction due to his significant risk history. Further tests are necessary to confirm the diagnosis and identify the cause.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African-American male  Medical History: Record of hypertension and type II diabetes  both have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. The patient has a significant cigarette smoking history  a pack per day for 30 years. He has a family history of heart disease  with both his father and grandfather suffering from heart-related problems.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a 3-days history of progressive shortness of breath  particularly with exertion  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He experiences marked fatigue and weakness  and reports recent weight gain of almost 10 pounds within a week. Physical examination reveals noticeable signs of bilateral lower extremity edema  mild jugular venous distention  and crackles upon lung auscultation. His heart sounds include a third heart sound (S3 gallop).   These symptoms are characteristic of congestive heart failure. Further diagnostics for confirmation and treatment plan in line with the severity of heart failure is recommended.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  Caucasian male  aged 70  retired engineer.  Relevant Medical History: Hypertension  Diabetes Mellitus Type II  Myocardial Infarction (MI) 5 years ago with stent placement  ex-smoker (quit for 15 years)  and mild alcoholic  takes medications for diabetes and hypertension regularly.  Current Presentation: Presented to the emergency room with a 3-day history of progressive shortness of breath  significant fatigue  ongoing overnight paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and new-onset pedal edema. As per report  episodes of shortness of breath are exacerbated by exertion  with reduced performance in daily activities and profound fatigue. He mentioned unusual weight gain over the week due to noticeable bilateral leg swelling. He denied having any chest pain  burning  or tingling.   On physical examination: patient appeared tired  respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation: 95% on room air  Blood Pressure: 145/90mmHg  heart rate: 95 bpm  bilateral pedal edema observed and jugular venous distension noted. Crackles heard in lower lung fields on auscultation complemented by third heart sound (S3) on cardiac auscultation.  In sum  we have a 70-year-old male with a significant cardiac history including a past MI  and hypertension  presenting with signs and symptoms congruent with decompensated congestive heart failure.

Patient Details: A 68-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: Long-standing case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. History of smoking for about 20 years  but quit 15 years ago.   Presenting Complaints: Reports exertional dyspnea for the past 3 months  gradually worsening. Particularly strenuous activities lead to paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Reports recent weight gain and increasing lower extremity edema.   Physical Examination: Patient is tachycardic and tachypneic. Jugular venous distension present. Bibasilar rales noted on lung auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals displaced left ventricular apex beat along with a prominent S3 gallop. Bilateral pitting edema noted up to the level of the knees.  Assessment: Symptoms and physical examination findings consistent with chronic heart failure  potentially related to long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Immediate thorough management and investigation needed.

Patient Profile: A 75-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for the past 20 years  poorly controlled diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years  with peripheral neuropathy complication. Past smoking history (30 pack-years)  quit 10 years ago. No known drug allergies. A history of Myocardial infarction 5 years ago  with subsequent atheromatous heart disease.  Presenting Complaints: Patient reports experiencing increasing fatigue over the last month. He has increasing shortness of breath  especially when trying to sleep lying down  forcing him to use multiple pillows. He also reports frequent nighttime urination  swollen ankles  rapid weight gain and loss of appetite. He denies chest pain or palpitations.  Physical Findings: On examination  the patient appears slightly anxious and breathless. Bilateral pitting edema noted in lower extremities up to the mid-calf. On auscultation  lungs show bilateral basal crackles suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Heart sounds reveal a third heart sound (S3 gallop)  suggestive of increased atrial pressure. Mild abdominal distension with a fluid wave  suggestive of ascites.  In summary  we have a case of a 75-year-old male patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and ischemic heart disease presenting with symptoms suggestive of chronic congestive heart failure.

Patient Profile:  A 68-year-old African American male veteran with a medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and recurrent tobacco use.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a 2-week history of shortness of breath  especially on exertion  worsening leg swelling  and recent weight gain. He additionally reports intermittent chest discomfort over the past week  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  and reduced exercise tolerance. His symptoms have been progressively worsening and have severely impacted his daily activities.   Relevant History: Chronic hypertension well-controlled with lisinopril  diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus treated with metformin  a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history. There is no known family history of heart disease. Previous annual examinations have revealed cardiac murmurs and previous lower limb edema  however  this has substantially worsened in the past month.  Relevant Symptoms:  Shortness of breath  especially on exertion  worsening lower limb edema  weight gain  intermittent chest discomfort  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  decreased exercise tolerance.

Demographic: A 67-year-old Hispanic female.  Relevant Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes 12 years ago and with hypertension 9 years ago. She had myocardial infarction 6 years ago for which she has been on medication with beta-blockers and low-dose aspirin. She has a history of intermittent episodes of bronchial asthma. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a 2-week history of increasing shortness of breath particularly during physical exertion  worsened in the last 3 days accompanied with orthopnea. Patient also reports decreased exercise tolerance  fatigue  and occasional palpitations. She also complains of new-onset lower extremity swelling and a noticeable weight gain in the past week. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention  bilateral crepitations in the lungs  and pitting edema in the legs. There is no chest pain  cough  or fever. The patient appears anxious and uncomfortable.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Hernandez is a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a significant medical history of ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents to the hospital with progressive shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and bilateral leg edema. His symptoms began around seven days ago and have gradually worsened. On physical examination  you notice an elevated jugular venous pressure  irregularly irregular heartbeat  displaced apex beat  bilateral basal crepitations in the lungs  and pitting edema in lower limbs. His last HbA1c was 8% despite taking Metformin  and his blood pressure is poorly controlled despite being on two antihypertensives.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: Patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He is an ex-smoker and gave up smoking 10 years ago. His medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He has no known allergies.    Presenting Complaint: Patient has been presenting with progressive symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and fatigue for the past 6 months. Recently  the symptoms became more severe associated with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The patient also reports weight gain and swelling in the ankle and lower legs  particularly towards the end of the day.  Physical Exam: The patient appears dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. The patient's blood pressure is somewhat elevated at 140/90 mmHg  and the heart rate is 90 beats per minute and slightly irregular. Examination of the cardiovascular system reveals elevated jugular venous pressure  a laterally displaced apical impulse  and an S3 gallop. Pulmonary exam reveals bibasilar crackles. There is 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities.  This patient presentation suggests the presence of decompensated heart failure. Further diagnostic evaluation including laboratory tests and imaging studies (echocardiography) are needed to confirm the diagnosis and to determine the type of heart failure (HF with reduced ejection fraction vs HF with preserved ejection fraction)  and to identify an underlying cause. Also  given the history of diabetes and hypertension  it is important to evaluate the patient for the presence of additional cardiovascular diseases  including coronary artery disease and diabetic cardiomyopathy.

Patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presenting with progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  and lower extremity edema for the past two weeks. The patient reports paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and orthopnea necessitating 3 pillows for comfort sleep. Patient also complains of decreased exercise tolerance and has gained 5 pounds in the past 10 days. No chest pain  lightheadedness  palpitations  or syncope. Patient has been taking his usual medications including lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin but admits to high dietary sodium intake. Family history is notable for heart disease in his father  who died at age 60. Patient denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. PE reveals an elevated JVP  bilateral basal crackles in lung fields  and 2+ pitting edema of both lower extremities.

Patient Information: Mr. Diaz  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker.  Medical History: Has long standing history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) of 15 years and Hypertension (HTN) for 10 years. He was diagnosed with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) stage III about 5 years ago.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a 2-week history of dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and lower extremity edema. The symptoms have progressively worsened; now even activities such as walking to the bathroom cause breathlessness. Mr. Diaz also reports a recent unintentional weight gain of approximately 8 pounds and decreased urination.  Physical Examination: Upon physical assessment  the patient has bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities  jugular venous distension  and bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. He also has an irregular pulse with a rate of 100 beats per minute.  Relevant Test Results: Recent laboratory results show elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP)  elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  creatinine and fasting blood sugar. His EKG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy.   Impression: Mr. Diaz’s symptoms  physical examination findings  and recent laboratory results suggest acute decompensated heart failure  possibly due to poor control of T2DM and HTN  in the setting of CKD. His symptoms along with physical findings suggest that he is in fluid overload  correlating with the elevated BNP.

Patient Demographics: A 65-year-old African American male   Relevant Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago  with a 25 pack-year smoking history. The patient has been non-compliant with medication (Metformin  Lisinopril) for his conditions for the past six months.  Presentation of Relevant Symptoms: For the past week  the patient has been experiencing progressive shortness of breath on exertion  an increasing need to sleep with multiple pillows (orthopnea)  and waking up at night feeling breathless (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). He also reports noticing swelling in his lower legs and feet (peripheral edema) and has gained 10 pounds in the last two weeks. The patient feels fatigued frequently and has been experiencing reduced appetite.  Based on the presenting symptoms and medical history  the patient appears to be in congestive heart failure  likely precipitated by poor control of his underlying diabetes and hypertension. He displays signs of fluid overload  evidenced by peripheral edema  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Further diagnostic studies should be carried out to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of heart failure.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Hispanic male.  Presenting Complaint: Progressive shortness of breath  worsened exertional fatigue  and rapid weight gain.  Relevant Medical History: History of ischemic heart disease  hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and a prior myocardial infarction treated with a drug-eluting stent to left anterior descending coronary artery five years ago. Non-compliant with medications including ACE inhibitors  statins  and oral hypoglycemics. Former smoker with 30 pack-years of smoking history.  Examination Findings: Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. He looks uncomfortable with clinical signs of volume overload including bilateral pitting edema  jugular venous distension  and an S3 heart sound. Lung auscultation reveals crackles bilaterally.  Problem Representation: A 68-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and diabetes mellitus type II presents with a several week history of progressive exertional shortness of breath  fatigue  and rapid weight gain - findings consist with worsening heart failure. His blood pressure is elevated  he is tachycardic and hypoxic on examination  and has physical signs of fluid overload  suggesting decompensated heart failure. His non-compliance with medications and poor control of cardiac risk factors have likely contributed to his current presentation.

Patient Profile: Mr. Evans  a 72-year-old African American retired police officer  married  with two children  residing in Queens  New York.  Medical History: Mr. Evans was first diagnosed with hypertension twenty years ago. He also has a ten-year history of type II diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia. Despite being placed on antihypertensives  oral hypoglycemic agents  and statins  his diseases have been poorly controlled. He is a non-smoker  although he had a 20-pack-year smoking history until he quit 15 years ago. He reports no known drug allergies.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Evans presents with an approximate six-month history of gradually worsening dyspnea  initially only on exertion but now also at rest. He reports orthopnea  nocturnal paroxysmal dyspnea  and swelling in his ankles and lower legs. He denies angina  syncope  palpitations  or recent weight changes. However  he admits to having decreasing activity levels and overall fatigue. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension  bilateral crackles upon lung auscultation  a laterally displaced apex beat  possible third heart sound (S3 gallop) and bilateral lower extremity edema.  Problem Representation: Mr. Evans is a 72-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension  type II diabetes  and dyslipidemia  presenting with classic signs of heart failure  characterized by progressive dyspnea  orthopnea  nocturnal paroxysmal dyspnea and lower extremity edema. His hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  coupled with prior smoking history  all contribute to his high risk profile for developing heart failure.

Patient is a 70-year-old male with a pertinent medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and a 20-pack year history of smoking  presenting with progressive dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity edema. The patient reports that over the past two weeks  he experiences breathlessness when climbing just a flight of stairs and at night while lying flat. He noticed that his slippers have become tight  and he has gained six pounds in the last week. He also complains of fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. No chest pain  palpitations  or syncope noted. These symptoms suggest worsening heart failure.

Patient Information: Simply Basic  a 65-year-old African-American male.  Chief Complaint: Chronic fatigue  shortness of breath  and increased leg swelling.  Present Illness: The patient presents with a progressively worsening 3-month history of fatigue  reduced exercise tolerance  leg edema  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The patient has also been experiencing a persistent cough that produces frothy  pink-tinged mucus  indicative of possible pulmonary edema.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed with medication for the past ten years. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  although he quit five years ago. His father had coronary heart disease and died of myocardial infarction at 70.  Medication: The patient takes metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes and 50 mg of losartan once daily for hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he appeared chronically ill and had an increased respiratory rate. His blood pressure was 130/85 mm Hg  and heart rate was 88 beats per minute. His jugular vein was distended  and bibasilar crackles with dependent pitting edema were present in both lungs. On precordial examination  there was a laterally displaced apical beat and a galloping rhythm.  This clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of heart failure (likely systolic heart failure given the longstanding hypertension). The patient's symptoms of fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance  his physical examination findings of a displaced apical beat  edema  and the nocturnal symptoms of cough productive of frothy  pink-tinged sputum (indicative of pulmonary edema) all point towards left-sided heart failure. The patient's known history of hypertension and smoking  as well as pulmonary edema  suggests that the patient may also have ischemic heart disease as a precipitating cause of his heart failure.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. S  is a 67-year-old African-American male  retired banker  and a non-smoker who presents with worsening shortness of breath over the last couple of months. He reports a decreased ability to walk his usual distance without getting winded; he has to stop 2-3 times during half a block walk due to palpitations and shortness of breath. He also mentions waking up at night gasping for breath and has noticed increased swelling in his legs.  Relevant medical history:   Mr. S has a known history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. He was admitted twice over the past year for congestive heart failure. He has a family history of heart disease as his father was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease in his early sixties.  Relevant symptoms on presentation:   Clinically  Mr. S presents with tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. Physical examination reveals bilateral pitting edema at the ankles and a raised jugular venous pressure. Auscultation of the heart reveals a third heart sound (S3 gallop) and pulmonary crackles are audible in lower lung fields bilaterally.   Diagnostic evaluation shows an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide  worsening kidney function  and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction on echocardiography.  This presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of advanced congestive heart failure. The prognosis will need to be discussed with the patient considering his worsening symptoms  increased hospital visits  and further deterioration of cardiac function.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African-American male with a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and Type II diabetes present to the clinic.  Presenting Problem: The patient complains of increasing shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  and a persistently feeling tired over the last two months. He also reports weight gain and increased abdominal distension even though his appetite has been decreasing. He’s noticed that when he is flat on his bed  he feels breathless and has been sleeping with three pillows to cope with this. Examination shows bilateral ankle edema.  Medical History: His hypertension and diabetes diagnosis were established 10 years ago and the patient admits to a lack of adherence with taking his medications - metformin and amlodipine. He has no other relevant medical or surgical history. He quit smoking a year ago after smoking a pack per day for 35 years.  Problem Representation: This 65-year-old man with poorly controlled hypertension and Type II diabetes has presented with features suggestive of congestive heart failure  including exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  fatigue  and bilateral ankle edema. His long-term cardiovascular risk factors and non-compliance with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic therapy may have significantly contributed to this conclusion. An investigation including imaging and cardiac markers will be needed to confirm the diagnosis and establish the extent of cardiac dysfunction. His medication regimen also needs to be reassessed and re-emphasized to manage his chronic conditions effectively and decelerate further cardiac damage.

Patient is an 80-year-old African American male with a known history of ischemic heart disease  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  who presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past 2 weeks  worsened by minimal exertion. Patient also describes associated symptoms of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  easy fatigability  and another recent weight gain of 7 pounds. Physical examination reveals pitting edema in the lower extremities  jugular venous distension  and bilateral rales suggestive of pulmonary congestion. There is no chest pain  palpitations  or syncope to suggest a recent coronary event.

Patient Profile:  69-year-old African American male with a past medical history of chronic hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  non-smoker and takes medication regularly.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with new onset fatigue  shortness of breath  and intermittent chest pain. Over the last couple of weeks  he has experienced increasing difficulty laying flat in bed due to respiratory distress and has been sleeping on extra pillows to remain somewhat upright. His wife also noticed his legs look “swollen.” He reports gain of 10 lbs over the past week mainly due to generalized body swelling.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago and type II diabetes five years back. He has been regularly attending follow-up appointments and taking medications including Metformin 1000 mg BID and Lisinopril 20 mg daily. He has never been hospitalized before this episode.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient is tachycardic with a regular pulse. Blood pressure is 165/92 mmHg. He has jugular venous distension. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral crackles at lung bases and an S3 gallop. Lower extremity examination shows pitting edema.   Working Diagnosis: Based on the history  examination and patient's risk factors  patient likely has decompensated congestive heart failure. Given the presentation  ischemic cardiomyopathy secondary to longstanding hypertension and diabetes has high suspicion and should be further assessed.

Patient Profile:   A 72-year-old African-American male presents to the clinic.  Relevant Medical History:   He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.   Presentation:   He reports increasing shortness of breath  particularly with exertion over the past 3 months  and has also noticed swelling in his feet and ankles. Additionally  he has experienced a recent unintentional weight gain of about 20 pounds. He has had some episodes of waking up in the middle of the night  gasping for breath. He has also noticed that he is unable to lie flat in his bed due to a feeling of breathlessness.  Probable Diagnoses:  The symptoms of shortness of breath with exertion  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  pedal edema and rapid weight gain suggest congestive heart failure. His known history of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia increases his risk for developing heart failure.

Demographics: 68-year-old Caucasian male   Medical history: Known case of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes for the last 10 years  both managed with medication; history of three packs per week smoking habit for 30 years  quit five years ago; no prior issues of cardiological concern.  Current Presentation: The patient presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of steadily worsening symptoms of fatigue  rapid weight gain (around 10 pounds)  chronic shortness of breath particularly when lying flat  consistent cough that occasionally produces white  frothy sputum  and swelling in the legs and ankles. He reports of activity intolerance and waking up in the middle of the night gasping for breath. Examination reveals an elevated heart rate and blood pressure. Chest auscultation suggests loss of breath sounds at lung bases bilaterally. Cardiovascular examination reveals an S3 Gallop rhythm. The patient seems anxious and has a dusky appearance. His oxygen saturation on room air is 90%.

Patient: Mr. Anderson  74-year-old  African American male.  Relevant Medical History: Long-standing history of untreated Stage-II hypertension  type-II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. Last known HbA1c was 8.2 indicating uncontrolled diabetes. The patient smoked one pack/day for about 30 years and quit 15 years ago. Prior myocardial infarction approximately 5 years ago. No known history of cardiac surgeries or interventions.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion over the last three months  which has now advanced to dyspnea at rest. He also reports orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The patient has noticed that he appears to be gaining weight despite no changes in diet or physical activities. He has frequent dry coughs and reports a decrease in appetite. He also notes increased fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance.  On examination: blood pressure reads 165/95 mmHg  pulse is 88 beats per minute and irregular  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute while at rest  and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Jugular venous distension is observable. Auscultation of the heart reveals a third heart sound (S3 Gallop). Lung examination reveals crackles at lung bases. Lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema up to the level of the knees.  Summary Problem Representation: Uncontrolled hypertensive and diabetic 74-year-old male with history of myocardial infarction  presenting with symptoms of increasing fatigability  weight gain  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  indicating symptomatic heart failure.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  62-year-old African American male   Medical History: Known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 15 years  under poor glycemic control and sporadic use of antihypertensive. Ex-smoker  quit smoking 10 years back  prior history of 20-pack years. No known allergies.   Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Johnson presents with a 2-week history of progressive shortness of breath  exercise intolerance  fatigue  and unexplained weight gain. Also complains about nocturnal cough  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea suggestive of fluid overload. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral lower limb edema  rales at lung bases  and an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation  indicating signs of left ventricular systolic dysfunction. His blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg  pulse is 88 bpm  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Regular medications are Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily.  The leading problem representation for Mr. Johnson is Decompensated Congestive Heart Failure likely secondary to long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: Notable for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking history. No known previous diagnosis of cardiovascular disease. No prior surgeries. Family history significant for heart disease in patient's father who died at age 65 of myocardial infarction.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient is presenting with a 6-week history of increasing dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Additionally  he has noted swelling in his ankles and a weight gain of 10 pounds. His symptoms are causing significant limitation of physical activity. On physical examination  elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral rales at the lung bases  and pitting edema in lower extremities are observed. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and heart rate is 95 bpm. He admits to occasional chest pain and palpitations.  Based on the presenting symptoms and medical history  the patient is likely suffering from heart failure  with a suspected etiology of hypertensive and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Further diagnostic investigations such as electrocardiogram and echocardiogram are required to confirm this preliminary diagnosis and assess the extent of his heart disease. Additionally  appropriate management of his comorbid conditions is necessary.

Patient Information: Mr. Richards  a 72-year-old male.   Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath  increasing fatigue  and swelling in lower limbs.  History of Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing these symptoms for about three weeks. The shortness of breath tends to get worse with exertion  but has also been present at rest.  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for 15 years on medication  treated for myocardial infarction 10 years ago  and diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 12 years ago.  Family History: Father died of coronary artery disease aged 70. His brother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Review of Systems: Positive for orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. No cough  no chest pain  no palpitations. He also has decreased exercise tolerance  has gained weight over the past month  and has bilateral leg-edema.   Social History: Ex-smoker (25-pack years) quit 10 years ago  not an alcohol consumer  does not engage in regular physical exercises.  Physical Examination: BP- 140/90 mmHg  RR- 22 breaths/min  HR- 90 bpm regular  SpO2- 91% on room air. Evidence of bilateral pitting edema  elevated jugular venous pressure. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at lung bases. Cardiac auscultation reveals S3 gallop.   Lab Results: Elevated BNP  mildly elevated liver enzymes  HbA1c 7.8%  impaired kidney function (eGFR 50 mL/min/1.73 m^2  creatinine 1.8 mg/dL).   Imaging: Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and signs of pulmonary congestion. Echocardiogram to be done.  Problem Representation: Elderly male patient with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and previous myocardial infarction presents with symptoms of heart failure  including dyspnea  fatigue  and peripheral edema. Physical examination and investigations further support this diagnosis. His condition is likely exacerbated by poor control of his chronic conditions.

Patient is a 68-year-old African American male known with a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  presenting with progressive worsening shortness of breath  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and bilateral pedal edema over the past month. Review of systems was positive for decreased exercise tolerance  orthopnea  and fatigue. There is a prior history of myocardial infarction three years back  which was managed with medical therapy. Antihypertensive medications have been intermittently non-compliant. On examination  he was found to have elevated jugular venous pressure  bi-basilar crackles in the lungs  an S3 gallop on auscultation  and 2+ pitting edema in lower extremities. No chest pain or palpitations were reported. The patient does not drink alcohol or smoke. Family history was significant for heart disease in his father who died at age 59.

Patient Profile: Mr. James  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired account manager  long-term smoker with a history of hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History: Mr. James was diagnosed with hypertension approximately 8 years ago and has been controlling it with medication  although compliance has been suboptimal. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago and has been managing it with medication and dietary modification. He has been a smoker for about 40 years  averaging 1 pack per day. He has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise. There is no family history of heart disease. His medications include Lisinopril 10mg and Metformin 500mg twice a day respectively.  Presenting Symptoms : Over the last 2 weeks  Mr. James has been experiencing progressive exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and swollen ankles. He also complains of weight gain and marked reduction in physical activity due to fatigue and breathlessness. His symptoms seem to be persistent and worsened over time.  Possible Diagnosis: Given the presenting symptoms  his age  history of long-term smoking  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and diabetes  these symptoms likely reflect worsening heart failure. Further investigation with echocardiography  chest radiography  blood tests (including cardiac markers and B-type natriuretic peptide)  and cardiology consultation are needed to confirm this hypothesis and to further rule out acute coronary syndromes  valvular heart disease  and arrhythmias.

Patient Presentation: Mr. James  a 65-year-old African American male with a known history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 45 pack year smoking history  presents to the clinic with increasing shortness of breath  fatigue  and lower extremity swelling over the past month. He mentions that he has been finding it progressively difficult to complete his daily activities due to these symptoms. Further inquiry also reveals exertional chest discomfort and palpitations. He denies any significant changes to his diet or medication adherence lately. He has a documented history of poor compliance with the recommended diabetic diet and medications. His blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  and BMI is 30. An examination reveals bilateral lower extremity pitting edema and elevated jugular venous pressure. There are also crackles at lung bases and a displaced apex beat. His relevant family history includes a father who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 57 and a mother with type 2 diabetes.

Patient Profile: Mr. Smith  76-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease.  Presenting Complaint: Shortness of breath  fatigue and swelling of lower extremities.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith reports that over the last two weeks  he has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath particularly upon minimal physical exertion such as walking short distances  and recently when at rest. He also complains of feeling fatigued more easily than usual and has noticed progressive swelling in his legs and feet. His symptoms seem to be worse in the evening and when lying down.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and Type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago; both are generally well-controlled with medications. He had a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 5 years prior.  Medications: Amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 1000mg twice a day for diabetes.  Examination: On physical examination  the patient exhibited peripheral pitting edema  jugular vein distention  and crackles heard on auscultation of the lungs.  Problem: The above clinical features are indicative of congestive heart failure. Mr. Smith’s pre-existing medical conditions have increased his risk of developing heart failure. Prompt diagnostic testing and treatment adjustment is required to manage the condition and to alleviate symptoms.

Patient is a 75-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and recent myocardial infarction 3 months ago. He presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath on exertion and bilateral lower extremity swelling over a 1 week period. He also reports orthopnea  noting a need to use 3 pillows to sleep at night  associated with episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. There is no history of chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. Previously independent in his activities  he reports that now he gets winded while walking to the bathroom. Patient has a history of medication non-compliance including his diuretics and anti-hypertensives. On examination  elevated jugular venous pressure  bilateral crackles halfway up lung fields  and a displaced  diffuse apical impulse was noted. Extremities were cool to touch with 2+ pitting edema noted up to the mid-shins. Known smoker with occasional alcohol consumption  no drug use  or notable family history of cardiac disease. Review of systems is otherwise non-contributory.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Jackson  a 68-year-old African American male.  Medical History: Mr. Jackson has a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago. He also has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 3 years ago. He has a family history of heart disease and stroke.   Current Presentation:  Over the past month  Mr. Jackson notices increasing shortness of breath  especially during light physical activities such as walking to the mailbox. He also reports a recent weight gain of about 8 pounds and swelling in his feet and ankles. Additionally  he has had trouble sleeping  needing to prop his head up on several pillows to breathe easier. He also reports feeling unusually fatigued and has been experiencing periods of elevated heart rate and palpitations.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African-American male.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a progressive 6-month history of dyspnea  orthopnea  and edema of the lower extremities. His symptoms have impaired his ability to perform household activities and have resulted in decreasing exercise tolerance.  Past Medical History: His medical history is notable for a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  chronic renal disease  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 50-pack-year smoking history.  Family History: Patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of an MI; his mother passed away from stroke.  Physical Examination: Examination was significant for distended jugular venous pulse (JVP)  mild wheezing in the lung bases  a displaced and enlarged cardiac apex beat  liver enlargement  and pitting edema of the lower extremities.   Initial Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms along with medical history and physical examination findings make a provisional diagnosis of chronic congestive heart failure.

Problem Representation:  Patient: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male.   Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension  Type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  previous MI (Myocardial Infarction) 4 years ago  for which he underwent PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention).  Presentation: The patient presents with a chief complaint of progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past month. He also reports orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  occasional dry cough  fatigue and recent rapid weight gain. Exercise tolerance has reduced substantially and he gets breathless while performing activities that he could do easily before. He denies chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. He has been adhering to his usual medications.  Examination: Observations are BP 130/85 mmHg  pulse 95 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 93% on room air. BMI is 28 kg/m2. Evidence of +2 bilateral pitting edema in lower limbs. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral basal crackles. Heart sounds include a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.    Impression: The patient’s symptomatology indicates worsening congestive heart failure. He is currently NYHA (New York Heart Association) Class III. Decompensated heart failure is suspected given the dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and peripheral edema. The history of diabetes  hypertension  previous myocardial infarction puts him at high risk for heart failure. Further investigations  including EKG (Electrocardiogram)  Chest X-Ray  and Echocardiography  are warranted to assess heart function and guide treatment.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male with a documented medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and obesity  presented with progressive symptoms of fatigue  shortness of breath  and edema in lower extremities over the past two months. Recently  these symptoms have worsened  and he has also begun to experience unexplained weight gain and nocturnal dyspnea. He has been reasonably compliant with his antihypertensive medication  but control has been suboptimal. He has a history of noncompliance with dietary and exercise recommendations for his comorbid conditions. On examination  he was tachycardic and edematous with elevated blood pressure  an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation  and evidence of pulmonary congestion on chest auscultation. His lab investigations showed elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) and slightly impaired kidney function which is a new onset. There is no known history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction and no known family history of heart disease.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents to the clinic reporting increased shortness of breath  worsening fatigue  and swelling in his ankles over the past two weeks.   Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  and hyperlipidemia 2 years ago. His hypertension and diabetes have been poorly controlled  with his last recorded blood pressure being 160/98 mmHg  and his last HbA1c level was 8.7%. He is currently on Metformin for his diabetes  atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia  and Lisinopril for his hypertension. He has no known drug allergies.  Symptoms on Presentation: During the examination  he appears dyspneic whilst at rest and reports orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. His breathing rate is 22 breaths per minute  pulse 98 bpm  and blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg. On auscultation  there are bilateral inspiratory crackles at the lung bases and a third heart sound (S3) is noted. Bilateral pedal edema is also present along with an increase in jugular venous pressure.  Family History: His mother died of heart failure at the age of 75 and his father had an MI at age 63.  Social History: The patient is a retired mechanic  lives with his wife  and is a 40-pack-year smoker. His diet is high in salt and he admits to not practicing regular physical exercise.  This case suggests the patient likely has chronic congestive heart failure  probably from a combination of poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes along with his significant smoking history and poor lifestyle choices.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia and a 30-year history of smoking  presenting with progressively worsening shortness of breath over a couple weeks  associated with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has also noticed a 10-pound weight gain during this time and decreased exercise tolerance  currently unable to walk more than a few steps without feeling breathless. No chest pain or discomfort is reported. The patient also mentions lower extremity edema and increasing fatigue. There is no known family history of heart disease. Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pulse  bilateral rales upon lung examination  a displaced left ventricular apex  with an added heart sound (S3 gallop) heard  and 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally. His baseline vitals show a blood pressure of 145/90  resting heart rate of 86 bpm and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled type II diabetes  obesity and hypertension  presents with a two-week history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  exertional fatigue and intermittent chest pain. He reports a recent weight gain of 10 pounds and notes swelling in his lower extremities. Pertinent physical exam findings include bilateral ankle edema and bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/90 mmHg and heart rate is irregular at 110 bpm. EKG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy and echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 40%. Laboratories reveal mildly elevated B type natriuretic peptide (BNP). There are no fevers  chills  or signs of active infection. This constellation of symptoms  exam findings  and diagnostic results suggest decompensated heart failure.

Patient Profile: Mr. James  65-year-old African American male   Medical History: Known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. The patient also has a past history of coronary artery disease  treated with stenting 5 years ago. He has been a chronic smoker for 40 years. He has not been compliant with his prescribed medications due to financial constraints.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. James presents with progressive shortness of breath upon exertion for the last 3 months. The symptoms have acutely worsened in the last 5 days. He now experiences breathlessness on minimal activity and occasionally at rest. Mr. James reports orthopnea  needing to use three pillows to sleep  and wakes up in the middle of the night because of breathlessness. He also reports recent weight gain  increased ankle swelling  and fatigue. Recent meals have made him feel unusually full.  On physical examination  he has bilateral rales on auscultation of the lungs  a raised jugular venous pressure  pitting edema of the lower extremities  and hepatomegaly on abdominal examination. His blood pressure is moderately elevated.   These symptoms and findings are suggestive of decompensated heart failure. Further diagnostic evaluation including echocardiography to evaluate heart function  examination of kidney function  and management with a multidisciplinary team is to be considered.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  65-year-old male  Presenting Problem: Patient presents with the symptom of shortness of breath and overall fatigue that has been worsening over the last month.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a 10-year history of high blood pressure that has been inconsistent in its management. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago and has a long history of heavy smoking (30 pack years). He has no known allergies. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 70.  Symptoms: In addition to shortness of breath and fatigue  Mr. Smith reports occasional bouts of sudden weight gain  persistent cough  and swelling in the ankles  feet and stomach area. He also has been experiencing a decreased appetite and has had trouble concentrating recently.  Assessment: Given Mr. Smith's symptoms and his risk factors--including age  gender  smoking  high blood pressure  diabetes  and family history--the presentation is consistent with congestive heart failure. Next steps involve confirming the diagnosis with necessary tests like EKG  echocardiogram  and blood tests and identifying a suitable treatment approach.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African American man  Mr. J.D.  presenting to the emergency department.  Medical History: Has a long-term history of uncontrolled hypertension and Type II diabetes with poor medication adherence. Non-smoker but consumes alcohol occasionally. There's a strong family history of heart disease.  Symptoms on Presentation: Over the past month  he's been experiencing increasing shortness of breath  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  and fatigue on exertion. He also reports swollen legs and rapid weight gain over the past week. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  dizziness or syncope.   Physical Examination: On examination  he appears pale and fatigued. He's tachypneic with a respiration rate 24 breaths per minute  heart rate 96 beats per minute  Blood pressure 165/95 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop rhythm. Pulmonary examination shows bilateral basal rales. His lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema.  Assessment: Given the uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and associated symptoms of dyspnea  orthopnea  edema and weight gain  the working diagnosis is congestive heart failure (CHF). This will need confirmation through further investigations including full blood work  chest X-ray and Echocardiogram. Interventional strategies at this point include optimization of heart failure medication  re-evaluating and tightening control of hypertension and diabetes  and lifestyle modifications.  Plan: Comprehensive cardiology consultation for CHF assessment. Initiate diuretics for fluid overload. Adjust existing antihypertensive and diabetes medication regimen. Implement dietary and lifestyle modifications. Patient education regarding importance of medication adherence.

Patient Profile: 65 year old  Caucasian male  Relevant Medical History: Patient has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with Type II diabetes 7 years ago. There is also a history of moderate alcohol consumption and a 40 pack-year history of smoking. Familial history reveals that the patient's father died of myocardial infarction at 60.  Presenting symptoms: The patient presents with complaints of progressive exertional dyspnea for the past three weeks  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and orthopnea. He describes this as a gradual inability to walk distances he previously could without experiencing shortness of breath. Furthermore  he reports episodes of waking up in the middle of the night gasping for breath needing to sit up to relieve dyspnea. He has also experienced a rapid weight gain with associated lower extremity edema.   Physical examination reveals an obese male in mild respiratory distress. Cardiovascular examination reveals an S3 gallop and jugular venous distension. There is bilateral lower extremity pitting edema up to the mid-shin level. Lung examination reveals bibasilar rales.   Based on the clinical picture  the patient seems to be experiencing heart failure  likely secondary to long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and Type II diabetes  complicated by a poor lifestyle involving smoking and alcohol.

Patient Profile: 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Problem: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  persistent coughing or wheezing  and swelling in his legs  ankles  and feet for the past few months.  Medical History: The patient has a relevant medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  both of which have been controlled with different medications for 10 years. He also has a known history of excessive smoking and alcohol intake. Ischemic heart disease was diagnosed 4 years ago  managed with statin therapy. There is no known history of familial heart disease or cardiomyopathy.   Current Medication: Patient currently takes metformin for diabetes  ACE inhibitors for hypertension  and atorvastatin for his heart condition.  Physical Examination: On examination  there is bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Patient’s heart rate was irregular with a rate of 110 beats per minute. Auscultation revealed an S3 gallop and crackles in lower lung fields.  Given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation  the chronic symptoms are suggestive of congestive heart failure. Further investigations  including cardiac biomarkers  chest X-ray  and echocardiography  will be helpful in confirming the diagnosis and assessing the severity of the heart failure  which will guide the therapeutic approach.

Patient Presentation: A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  obesity and previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago  is presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath  fatigue and increasing lower limb edema for the past one week.  The patient reports difficulty in performing routine activities due to increasing fatigue and shortness of breath. The patient also describes orthopnea  having to sleep with 3 pillows at night. There is no reported chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. Recent weight gain of about 7 pounds within the last two weeks has been noted.  He is currently on medications  including metformin for diabetes  a beta-blocker  and a statin. He has a history of non-compliance with the medication regimen and diet control.  On physical examination  he is slightly anxious  tachypneic with respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and pulse rate of 95 beats per minute. On auscultation  faint rales can be heard at lung bases and displaced apex beat was noted on the cardiac exam. Lower extremities show 2+ pitting edema up to the level of knees bilaterally. No other significant abnormalities were found in the examination.   His known history of cardiac disease  symptoms of increasing breathlessness  orthopnea  and bilateral lower limb edema suggest a diagnosis of worsening heart failure.

Patient is an 82-year-old male with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with symptoms of progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past 2 weeks  palpitations  and lower extremity swelling. He also mentions a reduced exercise tolerance and reports instances of waking up at night feeling short of breath. Upon physical examination  he is found to have jugular venous distention  pulmonary crackles  and 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. There is also evidence of an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation. These findings are consistent with heart failure.

Patient's Initials: J.S.  Age: 67  Gender: Male  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath  persistent coughing  and swelling in lower extremities  History of Present Illness: Patient J.S. presents with a 2-week history of progressive dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  and peripheral edema. Associated symptoms are persistent nocturnal coughing  reduced appetite and increasing fatigue.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed 5 years ago with ischemic heart disease and type II diabetes mellitus. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but he quit 15 years ago. He maintains his diabetes fairly well with metformin.  Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72. Mother is alive with diabetes and hypertension.  Social History: The patient is a retired military officer; he does not consume alcohol and has a supportive family.  Review of Systems: The patient has noticed weight gain over the past week despite not eating as much due to reduced appetite.   Physical Examination: J.S. is conscious but distressed due to shortness of breath. Blood pressure reads at 140/90 mmHg  pulse 102 bpm  regular  RR 22 per minute and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation  jugular venous distension  bilateral crackles on lung bases  and pitting edema bilaterally up to mid-shin.  Workup: Chest x-ray shows signs of pulmonary congestion. The EKG shows evidence of previous myocardial infarction. Laboratory findings show elevated levels of N-terminal prohormone of brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP).  Impression/Diagnosis: These clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of acute decompensated heart failure.

Patient Information: 73-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: Shortness of breath  excessive tiredness  and rapid weight gain  Medical history: Hypertension for the past 15 years  managed by ACE inhibitors. Past smoker  quit 10 years ago. History of Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) two years ago. No family history of heart disease.  Symptoms: Patient has been feeling increasingly fatigued and has difficulty in performing daily activities. Additionally  he reports progressive shortness of breath during exertion over the last 6 months. The patient also noticed a rapid weight gain of about 7 pounds over the past week. Upon physical examination  jugular venous distension  pulmonary crackles  lower limb edema  and an enlarged liver were noted.   Assessment: The reported symptoms combined with physical findings and medical history suggest the possibility of decompensated heart failure. Further diagnostic tests  including echocardiography and variant natriuretic peptide level  are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and measure the level of heart dysfunction. Immediate steps should be taken to manage fluid overload symptoms. Based on the severity of the condition  the adjustment of his current hypertension medication and introduction of heart failure medication might be required  along with lifestyle changes.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with medication. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  followed by the successful placement of a stent. He is a former smoker having quit 20 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history.   Presenting Symptoms: For the past month  the patient has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath  particularly during physical activity but also while at rest in recent weeks. He also reports orthopnea  needing three pillows to breathe comfortably while in bed  as compared to one pillow prior. Additionally  he mentions frequent nocturnal urination  swelling in his lower extremities  and a recent weight gain of approximately 6 pounds over the past week. On physical examination  he showed signs of pulmonary congestion with rales heard on auscultation and the presence of pitting edema in both ankles.     Overall  these symptoms suggest that this patient is experiencing heart failure. His age  race  diabetes  hypertension  and history of myocardial infarction all significantly contribute to his risk profile.

Patient Presentation:   A 72-year-old African American male  with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath  orthopnea  and bilateral leg swelling over the past week. He also reports a 5-pound weight gain over the last 3 days. He denies chest pain  palpitations or recent infectious symptoms. His regular medications include lisinopril  metformin  and aspirin.   Smoking history: 1/2 pack per day for 40 years. Drinking history: occasional alcohol use. Exercise: minimal due to fatigue and exertional shortness of breath. His blood pressure is leading towards 140/85 mm Hg and pulse rate is 95 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pulsation  3+ pitting edema in the legs up to the level of the knees  and crackles are heard at the lung bases bilateral on auscultation. No cyanosis or pallor detected.  Lab findings: Natriuretic peptide level is highly elevated. Chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. He is in a normal sinus rhythm on EKG but echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction.   Clinical Impression: Decompensated Congestive Heart Failure.

Demographic Information: A 63-year-old African American male.  Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years. He has been on medications  but patient admits low adherence. His family history includes a father who died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He is an ex-smoker  quit smoking 5 years ago and has a significant history of heavy drinking.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a two-week history of worsening shortness of breath  both on exertion and at rest  associated with a dry cough. He also reports episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He notes his legs have been progressively swelling over the past week and he has difficulty in lying flat at night due to breathlessness. He also reports that he has been feeling a decreased capacity for physical activity. On clinical examination  the patient has notable peripheral edema  elevated jugular venous pressure  and bilateral basal rales in lung fields on auscultation. He also has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the apex along with laterally displaced point of maximal impulse. His resting heart rate was 90 bpm  and blood pressure was 155/98 mm Hg.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male  retired teacher  presenting with progressive dyspnea on exertion  orthopnea  and bilateral lower extremity edema over the past month. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 35-pack-year smoking history. Patient is currently on losartan 100 mg once daily and atorvastatin 20 mg once daily. He has not been medication compliant. His review of systems also reveals recent weight gain of about 10 pounds over the last month. On physical examination  patient is tachypneic with a rate of 22 breaths/minute. Mallampati airway classification shows type II. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals jugular vein distention  positive S3 gallop  and rales halfway up the lung fields bilaterally. Extremities show pitting edema bilaterally. All other systems are within normal limits.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian man  Medical History: Chronic hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago. Infrequent patient adherence to prescribed antihypertensive medication. Father died of myocardial infarction. No history of tobacco or alcohol use. First diagnosed with heart failure three years prior.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion over the past two weeks. He also reports increased fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. He mentions occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  but no chest pain. He has experienced swelling in his ankles and abdomen. Physical exam reveals elevated jugular venous pressure  the presence of a third heart sound  and bilateral rales in the lower lung fields. His BMI is 27  an increase from 23 six months ago.    Diagnosis: Congestive heart failure exacerbation likely due to poor adherence to antihypertensive medications.

Patient Profile:  Mrs. H  a 75-year-old African-American female  retired elementary school teacher  is non-smoker  non-drinker & lives alone.  Presenting Problem: Presents with worsening shortness of breath  fatigue  and progressive lower extremity swelling over the past 2 weeks.  Previous Medical History: She has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin  and stage 3 chronic kidney disease. No prior documented cardiac issues.   On Examination:  Notably  she appears to have pitting edema in both her lower extremities. Auscultation of the heart reveal faint bibasilar crackles in the lungs and a distended jugular vein  indicative of fluid overload. Her blood pressure is controlled and within normal range.  Working Diagnosis: Given her age  history of hypertension and diabetes  and the presence of edema with other heart failure symptoms  she is suspected to be suffering from congestive heart failure. Further diagnostic evaluation including an echocardiogram  EKG  BNP  and a full metabolic panel will need to be performed to precise the diagnosis and characterization of her heart failure.

Demographics: A 68-year-old African American male  Past Medical History: Hypertension for the past 20 years  type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  previous myocardial infarction with angioplasty 3 years ago  obese (BMI: 31)  and a 40-pack year smoking history.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the Emergency Department with symptoms of increasing shortness of breath  notable particularly when lying flat (orthopnea). He is also experiencing increasing lower limb edema and unusual fatigue. He mentions a recent increase in nocturnal urination (nocturia) and has been finding his regular activities increasingly difficult due to weakness and breathlessness. He also reports episodes of rapid  fluttering heartbeats (palpitations) and occasional bouts of dizziness.

Patient Profile: A 69-year-old African American male with a past medical history notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath  orthopnea  and increased lower extremity swelling. He also reports a lessening appetite and feeling fatigued more than usual.  Relevant Additional Information: These symptoms have increased in severity over the past three days. The patient denies chest pain but reports palpitations. The patient is compliant with his daily Lisinopril  Metformin  and Insulin regimen. He has had no recent illnesses or changes in his daily habits.  Symptoms on examination: On physical examination  the patient is tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. There is bilateral pitting edema in his lower extremities and decreased breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. His heart rate exhibits occasional irregularity on auscultation with an S3 gallop rhythm.  Provisional Diagnosis: Given the patient's history and examination findings  the primary problem appears to be congestive heart failure with the possibility of underlying arrhythmia  likely secondary to longstanding hypertension and diabetes. Further diagnostic testing is necessary to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Profile: Mr. Hernandez  a 71-year-old Hispanic male with a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and previous myocardial infarction seven years ago. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Complaints: He presents with an exacerbation of heart failure symptoms over the past two weeks. Notable symptoms include worsening dyspnea on exertion—progressing to the extent that he now gets breathless on light activities such as dressing  walking short distances  and bathing. He's also been experiencing an increased frequency of nocturia. Mr. Hernandez reports unexplained weight gain of about 10 pounds over the last month  potentially indicating fluid retention. No chest pain  palpitations or syncope noted. No reports of persistent cough  hemoptysis  or swelling on the limbs.   Background Medical History: He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension 15 years ago  which have been under fair control with medication. Details of the myocardial infarction seven years ago include anterior wall involvement  treated with primary PCI and subsequent dual-antiplatelets and statin therapy.   Physical examination: On examination  he appears generally well but dyspneic on minimal exertion. He has bilateral basal lung crackles and elevated jugular venous pressure indicative of fluid overload. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 90 bpm and regular  and oxygen saturation on room air is 90%. No peripheral edema noted.   The patient's clinical feature suggests decompensated heart failure exacerbation possibly due to poorly controlled hypertension. Further investigations like blood tests including BNP  full blood count  renal and liver function tests  chest X-ray  and echocardiography are needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide the treatment.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  who presents to the clinic today with worsening shortness of breath  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  increased lower extremity edema and abdominal distention over the past week. The patient also reported an unplanned weight gain of 10 pounds within one week and has increased difficulty in performing regular activities due to fatigue and weakness. It is also noted that a recent unresponsive increase in blood pressure along with elevated blood glucose levels are evident despite medication adherence. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  lightheadedness  fever  or recent illnesses. The patient is a former smoker and quit 8 years ago  but had smoked one pack per day for around 35 years. He seldom drinks alcohol and denies the use of any recreational drugs. His current medications include lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia. He presents to the clinic today reporting a two-week history of worsening dyspnea  orthopnea  and fatigue  particularly when performing routine activities such as walking his dog or going up the stairs in his home. He also notes that his lower extremities look more swollen and he has gained weight (about 5 pounds according to his home scale) in the past two weeks. He denies chest pain  dizziness  syncope or palpitations. His current medications include Metformin 500mg bid  Lisinopril 10mg daily  and Simvastatin 20mg daily. Family history reveals a father with a myocardial infarction in his mid-60s. He is a former smoker with 20 pack-year history and drinks socially. On physical examination  patient has bilateral lower extremity pitting edema  jugular vein distension  and rales on pulmonary auscultation. His heart sounds are regular without any murmurs and shows S3 gallop. Given this presentation and history  the likely diagnosis is decompensated heart failure.

Patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a known past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He presents to the emergency department this morning complaining of progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past week  particularly while laying flat (orthopnea)  and a chronic dry cough. On further questioning  patient reports occasional chest pain  palpitations  and ankle swelling. He has also noticed a recent unintentional weight gain. He denies any fever  chills  cough or recent travel. Patient's current medications include metformin  lisinopril  simvastatin  and baby aspirin. The patient actively smokes and has a 40-pack-year history of tobacco use. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure  three-pillow orthopnea  bilateral crackles on lung auscultation  a displaced apex beat  and mild lower extremity pitting edema. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg  HR 85 bpm  RR 18 bpm  and O2 saturation measures 92% on room air. No previous echocardiogram is available  and EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient has no known drug allergies.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old male  Caucasian   Presenting Problem: Shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  rapid heartbeat  abdominal swelling.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed twelve years ago and type 2 diabetes diagnosed eight years ago. He has been managing his conditions with oral medications but has been non-adherent to his treatment regimen recently. He has no known allergies and he is a current smoker  averaging a pack a day for the past 30 years.  Symptoms: Over the past two weeks  Mr. Smith has been experiencing worsening shortness of breath  especially while exerting himself physically  but recently even at rest. He has felt extremely fatigued and noted a rapid heartbeat on multiple occasions. He has also started to notice swelling around his abdomen.  Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. Smith is pale  in visible respiratory distress  and is mildly obese. His heart rate is elevated at 120 bpm  blood pressure is 160/95  and his oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. He has bilateral lower extremity edema extending to mid-shin. Lung sounds are diminished at the lung bases and distant heart sounds with a third heart sound detected upon cardiac auscultation. Abdominal examination reveals mild ascites. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Interpretation: Mr. Smith's symptoms of shortness of breath  fatigue  tachycardia  abdominal swelling  physical findings of peripheral edema  third heart sound  and ascites are consistent with decompensated heart failure. His longstanding history of hypertension and diabetes  combined with poor medication adherence and smoking  have potentially contributed to this presentation. The next step should be to confirm this diagnosis with requisite imaging and laboratory tests. Mr. Smith will likely require hospital admission for further management and stabilization.
